440.03  YIELD STREETS.
   The driver of a vehicle approaching a yield sign shall, in obedience to the
sign, slow down to a speed reasonable for the existing conditions and, if
required for safety to stop, shall stop before entering a crosswalk on the near
side of the intersection or, if none, then at the point nearest the
intersecting roadway before entering. After slowing down or stopping, the
driver shall yield the right of way to any vehicle in the intersection or
approaching on another roadway so closely as to constitute a hazard during the
time the driver is moving across or within the intersection of roadways.
   All vehicles shall be required to yield on the following streets at the
intersections designated:
      Shenango Valley Freeway making a right turn north onto South Irvine
Avenue;
      East Budd Street at the Shenango Valley Freeway making a right turn south
or a right turn north onto the Shenango Valley Freeway;
      South Water Avenue at West State Street, traveling north on South Water
Avenue and making a right turn to go east on West State Street; and
      The "on" ramp of the Shenango Valley Freeway traveling north from Dickons
Place.
(Ord. 4-78. Passed 2-22-78; Ord. 3-88. Passed 3-30-88.)
440.04  NO LEFT TURN STREETS.
   No vehicle traveling east on Silver Street shall turn left at its
intersection with North Oakland Avenue.
(Ord. 12-92.  Passed 7-22-92.)
440.05  NO PASSING ZONE.
   No vehicle shall pass another vehicle proceeding in the same direction on
the following street or portion of a street in either direction:
      Division Street from the eastern City limits to Stambaugh Avenue;
      South Dock Avenue from Wayne Place to the southern City limits;
      Fourth Avenue from McCleery Street to Hull Street;
      Hall Avenue from McCleery Street to Fisher Hill Street;
      Highland Road from Independence Court to North Myers Avenue;
      McCleery Street from Hall to Fourth Avenues;
      Prindle Street from South Oakland Avenue to Walnut Avenue;
      River Avenue from East Silver Street to Pitt Street;
      Stambaugh Avenue from Division Street to East State Street;
      East State Street from Pine Avenue to Buhl Court;
      West State Street from Irvine Avenue to State Line Road;
      Thornton Street from Hall Avenue to North Sharpsville Avenue;
      Walnut Avenue from Prindle Street to Liberty Street; and
      North Water Avenue from West State Street to West Clark Street.
(Ord. 4-78. Passed 2-22-78; Ord. 3-88. Passed 3-30-88.)
440.06  CLOSING OF STREETS.
   The Mayor may cause any street or portion of a street to be temporarily
closed at such times and places and for such periods and purposes as he may
deem expedient.
(Ord. 4-78. Passed 2-22-78.)
440.07  LIMITED ACCESS INTERSECTIONS.
   (a)   No vehicle, other than an emergency vehicle, shall enter onto Edgewood
Road at its point of intersection with Stambaugh Avenue, nor shall any vehicle,
other than an emergency vehicle, exit from Edgewood Road onto Stambaugh Avenue
at their point of intersection.
(Ord. 12-84.  Passed 8-21-84.)
   (b)   No vehicle traveling on Stambaugh Avenue shall turn right at its
intersection with East State Street, except from the designated right-turn
lane.
(Ord. 19-92.  Passed 8-26-92.)
440.08  PEDESTRIAN WAYS.
   No vehicle shall be operated on the following streets, roadways or alleys,
or on the designated portions thereof, and the same shall be specifically and
exclusively reserved for use by pedestrian traffic and shall be so
appropriately designated:
   That portion of an unnamed alley beginning at a point on the south right-of-
way line of East State Street, such point being approximately 115 feet east
from the intersection of the east line of Chestnut Avenue and the south line of
State Street; thence in a southerly direction along the west right-of-way line
of the unnamed alley, along City Lot 3-A-26, a distance of 95.5 feet more or
less; thence in an easterly direction across such alley, a distance of ten feet
to a point on the east right-of-way line of the unnamed alley, the same being
the southwest corner of City Lot 3-A-29; thence north along the west line of
City Lot 3-A-29 to the point of intersection with the south right-of-way line
of East State Street, being a distance of approximately 94.47 feet; thence west
along the south right-of-way line of East State Street a distance of ten feet
to the place of beginning.
(Ord. 5-85. Passed 5-22-85.)
440.09  SCHOOL ZONES.
   The following traffic regulations are hereby enacted because they are deemed
to be necessary for the protection of school children, at the places and times
hereinafter set forth:
   (a)   Between 1:00 p.m. and 3:00 p.m. on normal school days, Linden Street
shall be one way, eastbound, between its intersection with Case Avenue and its
intersection with North Myers Avenue.
   (b)   Parking shall be limited to one-half hour on the south side of Linden
Street, between its intersection with Case Avenue and its intersection with
North Myers Avenue, between 1:00 p.m. and 3:00 p.m. on normal school days.
   (c)   Parking shall be limited to thirty minutes on both the east and west
sides of North Myers Avenue, between its intersection with Linden Street and
its intersection with Alcoma Street, between 1:00 p.m. and 3:00 p.m. on normal
school days.
(Ord. 15-87. Passed 8-25-87.)
   (d)   Eastbound and westbound traffic on East State Street shall be
prohibited from turning onto Case Avenue on days when school is in session
between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 3:30 p.m.
   (e)   Eastbound and westbound traffic on East State Street or Linden Street
shall be prohibited from turning on the portion of Case Avenue between East
State Street and Linden Street between the hours of 7:45 a.m. and 8:45 a.m.,
and from 2:15 p.m. and 3:15 p.m., on days when school is in session.
(Ord. 18-92.  Passed 8-26-1992; Ord. 13-19.  Passed 11-20-2019.)
440.10  LANE DESIGNATIONS.
   (a)   All vehicles shall be required to turn left when traveling in a lane
designated "left lane must turn left," at the following intersections:
      East and westbound traffic on East State Street turning onto South
Oakland Avenue and North Oakland Avenue;
      Southbound traffic on North Oakland avenue turning onto State Street;
      Eastbound traffic on State Street turning onto Jefferson Avenue;
      Eastbound traffic on State Street turning onto Euclid Avenue;
      Westbound traffic on State Street turning onto Stambaugh Avenue;
      Eastbound traffic on State Street turning onto Case Avenue;
      Eastbound traffic on State Street turning onto Forker Boulevard;
      Westbound traffic on State Street turning onto Spencer Avenue;
      Northbound traffic on Spencer Avenue turning onto East State Street;
      Southbound traffic on Forker Boulevard turning onto East State Street;
      Eastbound traffic on State Street turning onto Buhl Boulevard; and
      Southbound traffic on Connelly Boulevard turning onto Dock Street.
   (b)   All vehicles shall be required to turn right when traveling in a lane
designated "right lane must turn right," at the following intersections: 
   Stambaugh Avenue turning onto East State Street.
(Ord. 16-92.  Passed 8-26-1992.)
440.99  PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE:  See Section
420.99 for general Traffic Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)
CHAPTER 442
Pedestrians
442.01   Use of white canes.
442.02   Duty of pedestrians and motorists re blind persons.
442.03   Obedience to traffic control devices and regulations.
442.04   Right of way of pedestrians in crosswalks.
442.05   Pedestrians crossing at other than crosswalks.
442.06   Pedestrians walking along or on highway.
442.07   Pedestrians soliciting rides or business.
442.08   Right of way of pedestrians on sidewalks.
 
442.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Rights and duties of pedestrians - see Vehicle Code §§ 3541 et seq.
   Pedestrian control signals - see TRAF.
444.03
   Duty of pedestrians upon the approach of an emergency vehicle - see TRAF.
466.03
   Pedestrian ways - see TRAF.
440.08
442.01  USE OF WHITE CANES.
   No person, unless wholly or partially blind, shall carry or use any cane or
walking stick on a public highway, which is white in color or white with a red
end or bottom. (Ord. 6-78. Passed 2-22-78.)
442.02  DUTY OF PEDESTRIANS AND MOTORISTS RE BLIND PERSONS.
   (a)   Any pedestrian or operator of any motor driven or other vehicle shall
yield the right of way to any totally or partially blind pedestrian carrying a
clearly visible white cane or accompanied by a guide dog and shall take such
precautions as may be necessary to avoid injuring or endangering the pedestrian
and, if necessary, shall stop the vehicle in order to prevent injury or danger
to the pedestrian.
   (b)   This section shall not be construed to deprive a totally or partially
blind person not carrying a cane or not being guided by a dog of the rights and
privileges conferred by law upon pedestrians crossing streets or highways, nor
shall the failure of a totally or partially blind pedestrian to carry a cane or
to be guided by a guide dog upon the streets, highways or sidewalks of the City
be held to constitute contributory negligence in and of itself.
(Ord. 6-78. Passed 2-22-78.)
442.03  OBEDIENCE TO TRAFFIC CONTROL DEVICES AND REGULATIONS.
   (a)   All pedestrians shall obey the instructions of a police officer or
other appropriately attired person authorized to direct, control or regulate
traffic.
   (b)   All pedestrians shall obey traffic and pedestrian control signals
erected by the officials of the City in accordance with the requirements of the
Commonwealth.
(Ord. 4-78. Passed 2-22-78.)
442.04  RIGHT OF WAY OF PEDESTRIANS IN CROSSWALKS.
   (a)   Whenever traffic control signals are not in place or not in operation,
the driver of a vehicle shall yield the right of way to a pedestrian crossing
the roadway within any marked crosswalk or within any unmarked crosswalk at an
intersection.
   (b)   No pedestrian shall suddenly leave a curb or other place of safety and
walk or run into the path of a vehicle which is so close as to constitute a
hazard.
   (c)   Whenever any vehicle is stopped at any crosswalk at an intersection or
any marked crosswalk to permit a pedestrian to cross the roadway, the driver of
any other vehicle approaching from the rear shall not overtake and pass the
stopped vehicle.
(Ord. 4-78. Passed 2-22-78.)
442.05  PEDESTRIANS CROSSING AT OTHER THAN CROSSWALKS.
   (a)   Every pedestrian crossing a roadway at any point other than within a
crosswalk at an intersection or any marked crosswalk shall yield the right of
way to all vehicles upon the roadway.
   (b)   Between adjacent intersections in urban districts at which traffic
control signals are in operation, pedestrians shall not cross at any place
except in a marked crosswalk.
(Ord. 4-78. Passed 2-22-78.)
442.06  PEDESTRIANS WALKING ALONG OR ON HIGHWAY.
   (a)   Where a sidewalk is provided and its use is practicable, no pedestrian
shall walk along and upon an adjacent roadway.
   (b)   Where a sidewalk is not available, any pedestrian walking along and
upon a highway shall walk only on a shoulder so far as practicable from the
edge of the roadway.
   (c)   Where neither a sidewalk nor a shoulder is available, any pedestrian
walking along and upon a highway shall walk as near as practicable to an
outside edge of the roadway and, if on a two-way roadway, shall walk only on
the left side of the roadway.
(Ord. 4-78. Passed 2-22-78.)
442.07  PEDESTRIANS SOLICITING RIDES OR BUSINESS.
   (a)   No person shall:
      (1)   Stand on a roadway for the purpose of soliciting a ride;
      (2)   Stand on a roadway for the purpose of soliciting employment,
business or contributions from the occupant of any vehicle; or
      (3)   Stand on or in proximity to a highway for the purpose of soliciting
the watching or guarding of any vehicle while parked or about to be parked on a
street or highway.
(Ord. 4-78. Passed 2-22-78.)
442.08  RIGHT OF WAY OF PEDESTRIANS ON SIDEWALKS.
   The driver of a vehicle emerging from or entering an alley, building,
private road or driveway shall yield the right of way to any pedestrian
approaching on any sidewalk extending across the alley, building entrance, road
or driveway.
(Ord. 4-78. Passed 2-22-78.)
442.99  PENALTY.
   ( EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
420.99 for general Traffic Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)
   Whoever, being a pedestrian, violates any of the provisions of this chapter
shall be fined five dollars ($5.00).
(Ord. 6-78. Passed 2-22-78.)
CHAPTER 444
Traffic Control Devices

   CROSS REFERENCES

444.01  COMPLIANCE WITH AUTOMATIC TRAFFIC LIGHTS REQUIRED.
   No person shall operate a vehicle at the intersections named in the
following sections of this chapter, known and designated as automatic traffic
light intersections, except in the manner described in such sections.
(Ord. 4-78. Passed 2-22-78. )
444.02  TRAFFIC CONTROL SIGNALS.
   (a)   Meaning and Application of Colored Lights. Whenever traffic is
controlled by traffic control signals exhibiting different colored lights, or
colored lighted arrows, successively one at a time or in combination, only the
colors green, red and yellow shall be used, except for special pedestrian
signals carrying a word legend, and the lights shall indicate and apply to
drivers of vehicles and pedestrians as follows:
      (1)   Green indication.
         A.   Vehicular traffic facing a circular green signal may proceed
straight through or turn right or left unless a sign at such place prohibits
either such turn except that vehicular traffic, including traffic turning right
or left, shall yield the right of way to other vehicles and to pedestrians
lawfully within the intersection or an adjacent crosswalk at the time the
signal is exhibited.
         B.   Vehicular traffic facing a green arrow signal, shown alone or in
combination with another indication, may enter the intersection only to make
the movement indicated by the arrow, or such other movement as is permitted by
other indications shown at the same time. Such vehicular traffic shall yield
the right of way to pedestrians lawfully within an adjacent crosswalk and to
other traffic lawfully using the intersection.
   C.   Unless otherwise directed by a pedestrian control signal, pedestrians
facing any green signal may proceed across the roadway within a crosswalk.
      (2)   Steady yellow indication.
         A.   Vehicular traffic facing a steady yellow signal is thereby warned
that the related green indication is being terminated or that a red indication
will be exhibited immediately thereafter.
         B.   Unless otherwise directed by a pedestrian control signal,
pedestrians facing a steady yellow signal are thereby advised that there is
insufficient time to cross the roadway before a red indication is shown and no
pedestrian shall then start to cross the roadway.
      (3)   Steady red indication.
         A.   Vehicular traffic facing a steady red signal alone shall stop at
a clearly marked stop line, or if none, before entering the crosswalk on the
near side of the intersection, or if none, then before entering the
intersection and shall remain standing until an indication to proceed is shown
except as provided in the following paragraph.
         B.   Unless a sign is in place prohibiting a turn, vehicular traffic
facing a steady red signal may enter the intersection to turn right, or to turn
left from a one-way roadway onto a one-way roadway after stopping as required
in the preceding paragraph. Such vehicular traffic shall yield the right of way
to pedestrians lawfully within an adjacent crosswalk and to other traffic
lawfully using the intersection.
         C.   Unless otherwise directed by a pedestrian control signal,
pedestrians facing a steady red signal alone shall not enter the roadway.
   (b)   Places Other Than Intersections. In the event that an official traffic
control signal is erected and maintained at a place other than an intersection,
the provisions of this section shall be applicable except as to those
provisions which by their nature can have no application. Any stop required
shall be made at a sign or marking on the pavement indicating where the stop
shall be made, but in the absence of any such sign or marking the stop shall be
made at the signal.
   (c)   Inoperable or Malfunctioning Signal. If a traffic control signal is
out of operation or is not functioning properly, vehicular traffic facing a:
      (1)   Green or yellow signal may proceed with caution as indicated in
paragraphs (a)(1) and (2) hereof;
      (2)   Red or completely unlighted signal shall stop in the same manner as
a stop sign, and the right to proceed shall be subject to the rules applicable
after making a stop at a stop sign.
(Ord. 4-78. Passed 2-22-78.)
444.03  PEDESTRIAN CONTROL SIGNALS.
   Whenever special pedestrian control signals exhibiting the words "Walk" or
"Don't Walk" are in place, the signals shall indicate as follows:
   (a)   "Walk." Pedestrians facing the signal shall proceed across the roadway
in the direction of the signal and shall be given the right of way by the
drivers of all vehicles.
   (b)   "Don't Walk." Pedestrians shall not start to cross the roadway in the
direction of the signal, but any pedestrian who has partially completed his
crossing on the "Walk" signal shall proceed to a sidewalk or safety zone while
the "Don't Walk" signal is showing.
   (c)   Flashing "Walk." Whenever the "Walk" indication is flashing,
pedestrians facing the signal are cautioned that there is a possible hazard
from turning vehicles, but pedestrians may proceed across the roadway in the
direction of the signal indication and shall be given the right of way by
drivers of all vehicles.
   (d)   Flashing "Don't Walk." Whenever the "Don't Walk" indication is
flashing, pedestrians shall not start to cross the roadway in the direction of
the indication, but any pedestrian who has partially completed his crossing
during the "Walk" indication shall proceed to a sidewalk or safety zone, and
all drivers of vehicles shall yield to the pedestrian.
(Ord. 4-78. Passed 2-22-78.)
444.04  FLASHING SIGNALS.
   Whenever a flashing red or yellow signal is used in a traffic signal or with
a traffic sign it shall require obedience by vehicular traffic as follows:
   (a)   Flashing Red. When a red lens is illuminated with rapid intermittent
flashes, drivers of vehicles shall stop in the same manner as at a stop sign,
and the right to proceed shall be subject to the rules applicable after making
a stop at a stop sign.
   (b)   Flashing Yellow. When a yellow lens is illuminated with rapid
intermittent flashes, drivers of vehicles may proceed through the intersection
or past such signal only with caution.
(Ord. 4-78. Passed 2-22-78.)
444.05  TRAFFIC LIGHTS AT PARTICULAR INTERSECTIONS.
   (a)   Intersections Listed. Officials of the City have erected automatic
traffic light signals, in accordance with the requirements of the Commonwealth,
at the following intersections:
   Addison Road and South Irvine Avenue.

   East Connelly Boulevard and Service Avenue.
   East Connelly Boulevard and South Sharpsville Avenue.
   East Connelly Boulevard and Smith Avenue.
   East Connelly Boulevard and South Myers Avenue.
   East Connelly Boulevard and Spencer Avenue.
   East Connelly Boulevard and Stambaugh Avenue.
   West Connelly Boulevard and South Irvine Avenue and Columbia Steet.
   Davis Street at South Irvine Avenue.
   Division Street and Stambaugh Avenue.
   South Dock Avenue at National Castings entrance.
   Emanuel Place at South Irvine Avenue.
   Logan Avenue and South Irvine Avenue.
   North Oakland Avenue and East Silver Street.
   North Sharpsville Avenue and Meek Street.
   North Sharpsville Avenue and Pitt Street.
   North Sharpsville Avenue and East Silver Street.
   Shenango Valley Freeway and East Connelly Boulevard.
   Shenango Valley Freeway and South Irvine Avenue.
   Shenango Valley Freeway and Liberty Street.
   East Silver Street and Penn Avenue.

   (b)   "Stop Here on Red" Signs.  All vehicles shall stop at the spot
designated by "Stop Here on Red" signs at the following designated
intersections:
   In a southerly direction on Stambaugh Avenue at the East Side Fire Station
at East Connelly Boulevard.
   In a southerly direction on Smith Avenue at East Connelly Boulevard.
   In an easterly direction on East State Street at Smith Avenue.
   In an easterly direction on East State Street at Stambaugh Avenue.
   (c)   Stopping at Stop Bars or Lines.  All vehicles shall stop for the stop

   (d)   Right Turns on Red Prohibited. All vehicles shall stop for the steady
red indication at the traffic control signals and shall not be permitted to

   Case Avenue turning onto East State Street between 7:30 a.m. and 3:30 p.m.;
   East Connelly Boulevard and South Myers Avenue:
   Westbound on Connelly Boulevard turning northbound on South Myers Avenue.
   Forker Boulevard turning onto East State Street between 7:30 a.m. and 3:30
p.m.;

   Silver Street turning onto North Oakland Avenue;

   State Street turning onto Forker Boulevard; State Street turning onto
Spencer Avenue;
   West State Street at Irvine Avenue:

   West State Street and Water Avenues:
   Westbound and eastbound on West State Street, turning southbound on South
   Water Avenue or northbound onto North Water Avenue, and southbound on North
Water Avenue turning westbound onto West State Street.
(Ord. 4-78. Passed 2-22-78; Ord. 21-83. Passed 7-21-83; Ord. 35-83. Passed 12-
29-83; Ord. 3-88. Passed 3-30-88; Ord. 17-92. Passed 8-26-92; Ord. 1-94. Passed
3-24-94; Ord. 09-03.  Passed 8-21-03.)
444.06  DISPLAY OF UNAUTHORIZED SIGNS, SIGNALS OR MARKINGS.
   (a)   No person shall place, maintain or display upon or in view of any
authorized sign, signal, marking or device a sign, signal, marking or device
which purports to be or is an imitation of or resembles an official traffic
control device, or which attempts to direct the movement of traffic, or which
hides from view or interferes with the effectiveness of an official traffic
control device.
   (b)   No person shall place or maintain, nor shall any public authority
permit, upon any highway any official traffic control device containing any
commercial advertising except for business signs included as part of official
motorist service panels approved by the Pennsylvania Department of
Transportation.
   (c)   Every prohibited sign, signal, marking or device is hereby declared to
be a public nuisance and the City shall remove the same or cause it to be
removed immediately at the reasonable expense of the person placing,
maintaining or displaying the sign, signal, marking or device.
   (d)   No sign prohibiting parking shall be displayed any place in the City
by any person except in compliance with this Traffic Code.
(Ord. 4-78. Passed 2-22-78.)
444.99  PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
420.99 for general Traffic Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)
   Whoever violates Section
444.06 shall be fined not less than one dollar ($1.00) nor more than three
hundred dollars ($300.00).
(Ord. 4-78. Passed 2-22-78.)

CHAPTER 460

   Abandoned vehicles and cargos - see Vehicle Code § 7301 et seq.
   Obstructions of public ways and places - see GEN. OFF.
660.03
   Impounding - see TRAF. Ch.
422
   Parking - see TRAF. Ch.
480
460.01  DEFINITIONS.
   Unless otherwise expressly stated, words and phrases used in this chapter
shall have the meg.nings ascribed to them in the Vehicle Code of Pennsylvania,
as now in force or as hereafter amended, enacted or re-enacted, except when the
context clearly indicates a different meaning.
   (a)   "Abandoned vehicle" means a vehicle the physical possession or control
of which has been voluntarily or intentionally relinquished or disclaimed by
its owner without reference to any particular person or purpose and without the
intention of returning to reclaim or appropriate such vehicle.
   (b)   "Nonoperating vehicle" means any vehicle which does not display
thereon a current Pennsylvania registration plate and inspection sticker, or if
such current registration plate and inspection sticker are displayed thereon,
does not meet the requirements of the Vehicle Code of Pennsylvania concerning
the condition of vehicles and the necessary equipment to be attached to
vehicles in order to pass current State inspection standards.
   (c)   "Property" means any real property within the City which is not a
street or highway.
   (d)   "Street or highway" means the entire width between the boundary lines
of every publicly maintained street, avenue, highway, road, lane, alley or
public thoroughfare, however designated, including all existing berms and
rights of way.
(Ord. 16-70. Passed 7-22-70.)
460.02  ABANDONMENT OF VEHICLES.
   No person shall permit any abandoned vehicle to remain within the City and
no person shall leave any vehicle at any place within the City for such time
and under such circumstances as to cause such vehicle reasonably to appear to
have been abandoned.
(Ord. 16-70. Passed 7-22-70.)
460.03  LEAVING WRECKED OR NONOPERATING VEHICLES ON STREET.
   No person shall leave any partially dismantled, nonoperating, wrecked or
junked vehicle on any street or highway within the City.
(Ord. 16-70. Passed 7-22-70.)
460.04  DISPOSITION OF WRECKED OR DISCARDED VEHICLE.
   Upon receipt of written notice from the Chief of Police or other person
designated by Council, no person in charge or control of any property within
the City, whether as owner, tenant, occupant, lessee or otherwise, shall allow
any partially dismantled, nonoperating, wrecked, junked or abandoned vehicle to
remain on such property more than thirty days after receipt of such notice, and
no person shall leave any such vehicle on any property within the City for more
than thirty days after receipt of notice from the proper City official that he
is in violation of any of the provisions of this chapter.
(Ord. 16-70. Passed 7-22-70.)
460.05  EXCEPTIONS.
   This chapter shall not apply to any vehicle in an enclosed building; a
vehicle on the premises of a business enterprise operated in a lawful place and
manner, when necessary to the operation of such business or enterprise; or a
vehicle in an appropriate storage place or depository maintained in a lawful
place and manner within the City.
(Ord. 16-70. Passed 7-22-70.)
460.06  SEPARATE OFFENSES.
   A separate offense shall be deemed committed each day during or on which a
violation or noncompliance occurs or continues after notice thereof from the
proper City official.
(Ord. 16-70. Passed 7-22-70.)
460.99  PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
420.99 for general Traffic Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)

462.01  COMPLIANCE REQUIRED.
   (a)   No person shall do any act prohibited or fail to perform any act
required in this chapter.
   (b)   No parent of any child or guardian of any ward shall authorize or
knowingly permit the child or ward to violate any of the provisions of this
chapter.
(Ord. 5-78. Passed 2-22-78.)
462.02  PEDALCYCLE DEFINED.
   As used in this chapter, "pedalcycle" means a vehicle propelled by human
powered pedals.
(Ord. 5-78. Passed 2-22-78.)
462.03  LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person who resides within the City shall ride or propel a pedalcycle on
any street or upon any public path set aside for the exclusive use of
pedalcycles unless such pedal-cycle has been licensed and a license plate is
attached thereto as provided herein.
(Ord. 5-78. Passed 2-22-78.)
462.04  LICENSE APPLICATION.
   Application for a pedalcycle license and license plate shall be made upon a
form provided by the City and shall be made to the Bureau of Fire. An annual
license fee of fifty cents (500 shall be paid to the City before each license
or a renewal thereof is granted.
(Ord. 5-78. Passed 2-22-78.)
462.05  ISSUANCE OF LICENSE.
   (a)   The Bureau of Fire, upon receiving proper application therefor, is
authorized to issue a pedalcycle license which shall be effective for the
balance of that calendar year.
   (b)   The Bureau of Fire shall not issue a license for any pedalcycle when
it knows or has reason to believe that the applicant is not the owner of or
entitled to the possession of such pedalcycle.
   (c)   The Bureau of Fire shall keep a record of the number of each license
plate, the date issued, the name and address of the person for whom issued and
all pedalcycle license fees collected.
   (d)   The Bureau of Fire shall furnish to the Bureau of Police a duplicate
card showing the information set forth in subsection (c) hereof.
(Ord. 5-78. Passed 2-22-78.)
462.06  LICENSE PLATE.
   (a)   The Bureau of Fire, upon issuing a pedalcycle license, shall also
issue a license plate bearing the license number assigned to the pedalcycle,
the name of the City and the calendar year for which issued.
   (b)   The Bureau of Fire shall cause such license plate to be firmly
attached to the rear mudguard or frame of the pedalcycle for which issued, in
such a position as to be plainly visible from the rear.
   (c)   No person shall remove a license plate from a pedalcycle during the
period for which issued except upon transfer of ownership or in the event the
pedalcycle is dismantled and no longer operated upon any street in the City.
   (d)   No person shall willfully or maliciously remove, destroy, mutilate or
alter the number of any pedalcycle frame or part thereof registered pursuant to
this chapter.
   However, nothing in this chapter shall prohibit the Bureau of Fire from
stamping numbers on the frames of pedalcycles on which no serial number can be
found or on which such number is illegible or insufficient for identification
purposes.
(Ord. 5-78. Passed 2-22-78.)
462.07  INSPECTION OF PEDALCYCLES.
   The Bureau of Fire shall inspect each pedalcycle before licensing the ,same
and shall refuse a license for any pedalcycle which it determines is unsafe for
riding.
(Ord. 5-78. Passed 2-22-78.)
462.08  RENEWAL OF LICENSES.
   Upon the expiration of any pedalcycle license the same may be renewed upon
application and payment of the fee set forth in Section
462.04.
(Ord. 5-78. Passed 2-22-78.)
462.09  TRANSFER OF OWNERSHIP.
   Upon the sale or other transfer of a licensed pedalcycle, the licensee shall
remove the license plate and shall surrender the same to the Bureau of Fire or
may, upon proper application and payment of twenty-five cents (250), have such
plate assigned to another pedalcycle owned by the applicant.
(Ord. 5-78. Passed 2-22-78.)
462.10  RENTAL AGENCIES.
   A rental agency shall not rent or offer any pedalcycle for rent unless the
pedalcycle is licensed and a license plate attached thereto, as provided
herein, and unless such pedalcycle is equipped with the equipment required in
this chapter.
(Ord. 5-78. Passed 2-22-78.)
462.11  PEDALCYCLE DEALERS.
   Every person engaged in the business of buying or selling new or secondhand
pedal-cycles shall make a report to the Bureau of Fire of every pedalcycle
purchased or sold by such dealer, giving the name and address of the person
from whom purchased or to whom sold, a description of such pedalcycle by name
or make, the frame number thereof, and the number of the license plate, if any,
found thereon.
(Ord. 5-78. Passed 2-22-78.)
462.12  APPLICABILITY OF TRAFFIC ORDINANCES TO PEDALCYCLES.
   (a)   Every person riding a pedalcycle upon a roadway shall be granted all
of the rights and shall be subject to all of the duties applicable to the
driver of a vehicle by traffic ordinances of the City and by the Vehicle Code
of the Commonwealth, except as to those provisions of ordinances which by their
nature can have no application.
   (b)   The provisions of this chapter apply whenever a pedalcycle is operated
upon a highway or upon any path set aside for the exclusive use of pedalcycles
subject to the exceptions stated in subsection (a) hereof.
(Ord. 5-78. Passed 2-22-78.)
462.13  OBEDIENCE TO TRAFFIC CONTROL DEVICES.
   (a)   Any person operating a pedalcycle shall obey the instructions of
official t) affic signals, signs and other control devices applicable to
vehicles.
   (b)   Whenever authorized signs are erected indicating that no right, left
or "U' turn is permitted, no person operating a pedalcycle shall disobey the
direction of any such sign, except where such person dismounts from the
pedalcycle to make such turn, in which event such person shall then obey the
regulations applicable to pedestrians.
(Ord. 5-78. Passed 2-22-78.)
462.14  RIDING ON PEDALCYCLES.
   (a)   A person propelling a pedalcycle shall not ride other than upon or
astride a permanent and regular seat attached to the pedalcycle.
   (b)   No pedalcycle shall be used to carry more persons at one time than the
number for which the pedalcycle is designed and equipped except that an adult
rider may carry a child securely attached to the rider in a backpack or sling.
(Ord. 5-78. Passed 2-22-78.)
462.15  SPEED.
   No person shall operate a pedalcycle at a speed greater than is reasonable
and prudent under the conditions then existing.
(Ord. 5-78. Passed 2-22-78.)
462.16  RIDING ON ROADWAYS AND PEDALCYCLE PATHS.
   (a)   Every person operating a pedalcycle upon a roadway shall ride as near
the right side of the roadway as is practicable, exercising due care when
passing a standing vehicle or one proceeding in the same direction.
   (b)   Any person operating a pedalcycle upon a roadway of a highway, which
highway carries traffic in one direction only and has two or more marked
traffic lanes, may ride as near the left-hand curb or edge of the roadway as
practicable, exercising due care when passing a standing vehicle or one
proceeding in the same direction.
   (c)   Whenever a lane or path for pedalcycles has been provided as part of a
highway, pedalcycle riders shall use the lane or path and shall not use any
other part of the highway. This subsection does not apply when use of the
pedalcycle lane or path is not possible, safe or reasonable.
(Ord. 5-78. Passed 2-22-78.)
462.17  EMERGING FROM ALLEY OR DRIVEWAY.
   The operator of a pedalcycle emerging from an alley, driveway or building
shall, upon approaching a sidewalk or the sidewalk area extending across any
alleyway, yield the right of way to all pedestrians approaching on such
sidewalk or sidewalk area and upon entering the roadway shall yield the right
of way to all vehicles approaching on such roadway.
(Ord. 5-78. Passed 2-22-78.)
462.18  CLINGING TO VEHICLES.
   No person riding upon a pedalcycle shall attach the same or himself to any
other vehicle upon a roadway.
(Ord. 5-78. Passed 2-22-78.)
462.19  LIMITATION ON RIDING ABREAST.
   Persons riding pedalcycles upon a roadway shall not ride more than two
abreast except on paths or parts of roadways set aside for the exclusive use of
pedalcycles.
(Ord. 5-78. Passed 2-22-78.)
462.20  ARTICLES CARRIED BY OPERATOR.
   No person operating a pedalcycle shall carry any package, bundle or article
which prevents the driver from keeping at least one hand upon the handlebars.
(Ord. 5-78. Passed 2-22-78.)
462.21  PARKING.
   (a)   Sidewalks.
      (1)   A person may park a pedalcycle on a sidewalk unless prohibited or
restricted by an official traffic control device.
      (2)   A pedalcycle parked on a sidewalk shall not impede the normal and
reasonable movement of pedestrian or other traffic.
   (b)   Roadways.
      (1)   A pedalcycle may be parked on the roadway at any angle to the curb
or edge of the roadway at any location where parking is permitted.
      (2)   A pedalcycle may be parked on the roadway abreast of another
pedalcycle or pedalcycles near the side of the roadway at any location where
parking is allowed.
      (3)   A person shall not park a pedalcycle on a roadway in such a manner
as to obstruct the movement of a legally parked motor vehicle.
      (4)   In all other respects, pedalcycles parked anywhere on a highway
shall conform with the provisions of the traffic ordinances of the City and the
Vehicle Code of the Commonwealth.
(Ord. 5-78. Passed 2-22-78.)
462.22  RIDING ON SIDEWALKS.
   No person shall ride a pedalcycle upon a sidewalk within the City.
(Ord. 5-78. Passed 2-22-78.)
462.23  LAMPS AND OTHER EQUIPMENT ON PEDALCYCLES.
   Every pedalcycle when in use between sunset and sunrise shall be equipped on
the front with a lamp which emits a white light visible from a distance of at
least 500 feet to the front and with a red reflector on the rear of a type
approved by the Department of Transportation which shall be visible from all
distances from 100 feet to 600 feet to the rear and with an amber reflector on
each side. A lamp emitting a red light visible from a distance of 500 feet to
the rear may be used in addition to the red reflector. A lamp worn by the
operator of a pedalcycle shall comply with the requirements of this section if
the lamp can be seen at the distances specified. All lamps and reflectors shall
be of a type approved by the Department of Transportation.
(Ord. 5-78. Passed 2-22-78.)
462.24  AUDIBLE SIGNALS.
   A pedalcycle may be equipped with a device capable of giving a signal
audible for a distance of at least 100 feet except that a pedalcycle shall not
be equipped with nor shall any person use upon a pedalcycle any siren.
(Ord. 5-78. Passed 2-22-78.)
462.25  BRAKES.
   Every pedalcycle shall be equipped with a braking system which will stop the
pedalcycle in fifteen feet from an initial speed of fifteen miles per hour on a
dry, level and clean pavement.
(Ord. 5-78. Passed 2-22-78.)
462.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any of the provisions of this chapter shall be fined ten
dollars ($10.00).
(Ord. 5-78. Passed 2-22-78.)

464.01  TRUCK AND TRAILER TRAFFIC.
   No truck or trailer, as defined in the Vehicle Code of Pennsylvania, having
a capacity of five tons gross weight or more shall be operated on the following
streets or portion of streets:
      Buhl Boulevard, both directions for the entire length.
      Highland Road, both directions for the entire length.
      Wayne Place, both directions for the entire length.
      Orchard Street, from its intersection with New Castle Avenue west to its
intersection with South Dock Street.
      Walnut Avenue.
      Sterling Avenue between Budd Street and Connelly Boulevard.
(Ord. 4-78. Passed 2-22-78; Ord. 26-94. Passed 1-26-95; Ord. 1-99. Passed 2-25-
99; Ord. 12-02. Passed 7-18-02.)
464.02  RESTRICTION ON USE OF HIGHWAYS.
   (a)   No truck or trailer, as defined in the Vehicle Code of Pennsylvania,
or combination thereof, shall be operated on the west side of Stambaugh Avenue
from Division Street to the rear property line on the south side of Union
Street. Trucks may be operated thereon for the purpose of delivering or picking
up materials or merchandise from or to residents or commercial establishments.
(Ord. 10-82. Passed 6-23-82.)
   (b)   No truck shall be operated on the Main Street Extension between Silver
Street and Bridge Place. The same shall be specifically and exclusively
reserved for use by non-truck vehicular traffic and truck traffic making local
deliveries.
(Ord. 16-87. Passed 9-23-87.)
464.03  OVERWEIGHT PERMITS; FEES.
   The proper City officials are hereby authorized to issue overweight permits
for vehicles operating within the City, in accordance with the provisions of
the Pennsylvania Vehicle Code, 75 Pa.C.S.A. 4968 and 75 Pa. C.S.A. 4961, as
amended. City officials may issue permits at a single instance, or for multiple
usages by an identified vehicle during a twelve month period. A fee of two
dollars ($2.00) shall be collected for each single instance permit issued,
unless, a permit is requested for a calendar year, in which case the fee shall
be five hundred dollars ($500.00) per each vehicle route permitted. Council
may, by resolution, amend the fee to be charged for the permit or permits,
provided, however, that any such amendment shall not affect permits issued
prior to the effective date of that amending resolution.
(Ord. 7-95. Passed 5-25-95; Ord. 14-03.  Passed 10-16-03.)
464.99  PENALTY.
   (a)   Whoever violates Section
464.01 shall be fined not less than two dollars ($2.00) nor more than fifteen
dollars ($15.00).
(Ord. 10-82. Passed 6-23-82.)
   (b)   Whoever violates Section
464.02 is guilty of a summary offense and shall be fined not less than twenty-
five dollars ($25.00) nor more than one hundred dollars ($100.00).
(Ord. 10-82. Passed 6-23-82.)
CHAPTER 466
Emergency Vehicles
466.01   Duty of drivers of emergency vehicles.
466.02   Duty of motorists.
466.03   Duty of pedestrians.
466.04   Equipment requirements.
 
466.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Exercise of special privileges - see Vehicle Code § 3105
   Traffic control devices - application of law - see Vehicle Code § 3111
   Duty of driver on approach of emergency vehicle - see Vehicle Code § 3325
   Right of way - see Vehicle Code §§ 3325, 3548
   Equipment, visual and audible signals - see Vehicle Code § 4571
   Obedience of ambulance drivers to traffic laws - see B.R. & T.
820.13
466.01  DUTY OF DRIVERS OF EMERGENCY VEHICLES.
   (a)   In General. The driver of an emergency vehicle, when responding to an
emergency call or when in the pursuit of an actual or suspected violator of the
law or when responding to, but not upon returning from, a fire alarm, may
exercise the privileges set forth in this section, but subject to the
conditions stated in this section.
   (b)   Exercise of Special Privileges. The driver of an emergency vehicle
may:
      (1)   Park or stand, irrespective of the provisions of this Traffic Code;
      (2)   Proceed past a red signal indication or stop sign, but only after
slowing down as may be necessary for safe operation, except as provided in
subsection (d) hereof;
      (3)   Exceed the maximum speed limits so long as the driver does not
endanger life or property, except as provided in subsection (d) hereof; and
      (4)   Disregard regulations governing direction of movement or turning in
specified directions.
   (c)   Audible and Visual Signals Required. The privileges granted in this
section to an emergency vehicle shall apply only when the vehicle is making use
of an audible signal and visual signals meeting the requirements and standards
set forth in regulations adopted by the Pennsylvania Department of
Transportation, except that an emergency vehicle operated as a police vehicle
need not be equipped with or display the visual signals.
   (d)   Ambulances and Blood Delivery Vehicles. The driver of an ambulance or
blood delivery vehicle shall comply with maximum speed limits, red signal
indications and stop signs. After ascertaining that the ambulance or blood
delivery vehicle will be given the right of way, the driver may proceed through
a red signal indication or stop sign.
   (e)   Exercise of Care. This section does not relieve the driver of an
emergency vehicle from the duty to drive with due regard for the safety of all
persons.
(Ord. 4-78. Passed 2-22-78.)
466.02  DUTY OF MOTORISTS.
   Upon the immediate approach of an emergency vehicle making use of an audible
signal and visual signals meeting the requirements and standards set forth in
regulations adopted by the Pennsylvania Department of Transportation, or of a
police vehicle properly and lawfully making use of an audible signal only, the
driver of every other vehicle shall yield the right of way and shall
immediately drive to a position parallel to, and as close as possible to, the
right hand edge or curb of the roadway clear of any intersection and shall stop
and remain in that position until the emergency vehicle has passed, except when
otherwise directed by a police officer. On one-way roadways a driver may comply
by driving to the edge or curb which is nearest to the lane in which he is
driving.
(Ord. 4-78. Passed 2-22-78.)
466.03  DUTY OF PEDESTRIANS.
   (a)   Upon the immediate approach of an authorized emergency vehicle making
use of an audible signal and visual signals meeting the requirements of the
Pennsylvania Department of Transportation, or of a police vehicle properly and
lawfully making use of an audible signal only, every pedestrian shall yield the
right of way to the authorized emergency vehicle.
   (b)   This section does not relieve the driver of an authorized emergency
vehicle from the duty to drive with due regard for the safety of all persons
using the highway or from the duty to exercise due care to avoid colliding with
any pedestrian.
(Ord. 4-78. Passed 2-22-78.)
466.04  EQUIPMENT REQUIREMENTS.
   (a)   Flashing Lights and Audible Warning Systems. Every emergency vehicle
shall be equipped with one or more revolving or flashing red lights and an
audible warning system.
   (b)   Police and Fire Vehicles.
      (1)   Police vehicles, in addition to the requirements of subsection (a)
hereof, shall be equipped with revolving or flashing blue lights. The
combination of red and blue lights may be used only on police vehicles.
      (2)   Spotlights with adjustable sockets may be attached to or mounted on
police vehicles.
      (3)   Unmarked police vehicles, used as emergency vehicles and equipped
with audible warning systems, may be equipped with the lights described in this
section.
      (4)   Police and fire vehicles may be equipped with a mounted rack
containing one or more emergency warning lights or side mounted adjustable
floodlights, or both.
   (c)   Vehicles Prohibited From Using Signals. Except as otherwise
specifically provided in this Traffic Code, no vehicle other than an emergency
vehicle may be equipped with lights or audible warning systems identical or
similar to those specified in subsections (a) and (b) hereof.
   (d)   Authorized Period of Use. The lights and warning systems specified in
this section may be used only during an emergency or in the interest of public
safety and by police officers in the enforcement of the law.
(Ord. 4-78. Passed 2-22-78.)
466.99  PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
420.99 for general Traffic Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)

opposite direction unless the movement can be made in safety and without

on the following streets and highways:

      Forker Boulevard from East State Street to the northern City limits.
      East State Street from the eastern City limits to the Shenango River.
      West State Street from Irvine Avenue to the Shenango River.

following streets and highways:

   (d)   No vehicle shall be operated on the Shenango Valley Freeway and
Connelly Boulevard at more than the posted speeds which shall be as follows:
      (1)   Forty miles per hour from the Ohio State line for a distance of
one-half mile to Station 29+75.
      (2)   Thirty-five miles per hour from Station 29+75 for a distance of
one-half mile to Station 57+0.
      (3)   Forty miles per hour from Station 57+0 to the eastern City limits.
   (e)   No vehicle shall be operated at more than fifteen miles per hour in
the following locations:
      (1)   In the Sharon Bicentennial Park; and
      (2)   On East State Street, between Forker Boulevard and Wengler Avenue,
between 7:30 a.m. and 4:00 p.m. on days when school is in session.

468.03  DRIVING ON ROADWAYS LANED FOR TRAFFIC.
   Whenever any roadway has been divided into two or more clearly marked lanes
for traffic, the following rules, in addition to all others not inconsistent
therewith, shall apply:
   (a)   Driving Within Single Lane. A vehicle shall be driven as nearly as
practicable entirely within a single lane and shall not be moved from the lane
until the driver has first ascertained that the movement can be made with
safety.
   (b)   Three Lane Roadways. Upon a roadway which is divided into three lanes
and provides for two-way movement of traffic, a vehicle shall not be driven in
any lane except that lane allocated exclusively to traffic moving in the same
direction that has been designated by official traffic control devices.
   (c)   Prohibitions Against Changing Lanes. Official traffic control devices
have been installed prohibiting the changing of lanes on sections of roadways
and drivers of vehicles shall obey the directions of every such device.
   (d)   Lanes Limited to Specific Use. Official traffic control devices have
been erected to restrict the use of specified lanes on the following roadways
and drivers of vehicles shall obey the directions of every such device:
   Addison Road and South Irvine Avenue
      In a southerly direction from Emanuel Place to Addison Road:
         Right-hand lane for straight through and right-hand turns only.
         Center lane for straight through traffic only.

         Right-hand lane for right-turn and straight through traffic only.
         Left-hand lane for left-turn traffic only.
      In a northerly direction on the Shenango Valley Freeway:
         Right-hand lane for right-turn traffic only.
         Left-hand lane for left-turn and straight through traffic only.
(Ord. 4-78. Passed 2-22-78; Ord. 27-80. Passed 9-10-80; Ord. 46-80. Passed 11-
12-80; Ord. 22-81. Passed 6-30-81; Ord. 25-81. Passed 9-23-81; Ord. 13-82.
Passed 7-28-82; Ord. 3-88. Passed 3-30-88.)
468.04  DRIVING ON DIVIDED HIGHWAYS.
   (a)   Whenever any highway has been divided into two or more roadways by
leaving an intervening space, physical barrier or clearly indicated dividing
section so constructed as to impede vehicular traffic, every vehicle shall be
driven only upon the right-hand roadway unless directed or permitted to use
another roadway by official traffic control devices, police officers or
appropriately attired persons authorized to direct, control or regulate
traffic. No vehicle shall be driven over, across or within any such dividing
space, barrier or dividing section or space or at a crossover or intersection
as established.
   (b)   No person shall drive a vehicle onto any limited access highway or
entrance to such highway to reach a place of business against the normal and
safe movement of traffic.
(Ord. 4-78. Passed 2-22-78.)
468.05  ENFORCEMENT.
   The Police Department of the City is hereby authorized to use all speed-
timing devices for the determination of speed of a motor vehicle as approved,
or may be approved, by the Department of Transportation of the Commonwealth of
Pennsylvania, in accordance with Title 75, Section 3368 of the Vehicle Code.
(Ord. 20-02. Passed 12-19-02.)
468.99  PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
420.99 for general Traffic Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)
   (a)   Whoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of
Section
468.02 shall be fined thirty-five dollars ($35.00) plus two dollars ($2.00) per
mile in excess of five miles per hour over the maximum speed limit.
   (b)   Whoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of
Sections
468.03 and
468.04 shall be fined not less than two dollars ($2.00) nor more than fifteen
dollars ($15.00).
(Ord. 4-78. Passed 2-22-78.)

480.05  OVERNIGHT PARKING OF COMMERCIAL AND HEAVY VEHICLES.
   All trucks, buses and other commercial motor vehicles are prohibited from
parking on any of the highways, streets or alleys within the corporate limits
of the City between the hours of 6:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. daily.
(Ord. 4-78. Passed 2-22-78.)
480.06  PARKING OF COMMERCIAL AND HEAVY VEHICLES ON OFF-STREET SYSTEMS AND
SITES.
   All trucks, buses and other commercial vehicles in excess of one-half ton
gross weight are prohibited from parking at all times on any off-street parking
system or site.
(Ord. 4-78. Passed 2-22-78.)
480.07  CURB PARKING.
   (a)   Two-Way Highways. Every vehicle standing or parked upon a two-way
highway shall be positioned parallel to and with the right-hand wheels within
twelve inches of the right-hand curb or, in the absence of a curb, as close as
practicable to the right edge of the right-hand shoulder.
   (b)   One-Way Highways. Every vehicle standing or parked upon a one-way
highway shall be positioned parallel to the curb or edge of the highway in the
direction of authorized traffic movement with its right-hand wheels within
twelve inches of the right-hand curb or, in the absence of a curb, as close as
practicable to the right edge of the right-hand shoulder, or with its left-hand
wheels twelve inches of the left-hand curb or, in the absence of a curb, as
close as practicable to the left edge of the left-hand shoulder.
   (c)   Angle Parking. Angle parking is prohibited.
   (d)   Double Parking. No vehicle shall be double parked at any time.
   (e)   Handicapped Persons and Disabled Veterans.
         (1)   When a motor vehicle bearing registration plates or a placard
issued to handicapped persons or disabled veterans is being operated by or for
the transportation of the handicapped person or disabled veteran, the driver
shall be relieved of any liability for parking for a period of sixty minutes in
excess of the legal parking period permitted by this Traffic Code except when
this Traffic Code or a police regulation provides for the accommodation of
heavy traffic during morning, afternoon or evening hours.
         (2)   At the request of any handicapped person or disabled veteran,
local authorities may erect on the highway, as closely as possible to their
place of residence, a sign or signs indicating that the place is reserved for a
handicapped person or disabled veteran, that no parking is allowed there by
others, and that any unauthorized person parking there shall be subject to a
fine.
(Ord. 4-78. Passed 2-22-78; Ord. 3-88. Passed 3-30-88.)
480.08  PARKING PROHIBITED IN SPECIFIED PLACES.
   (a)   Prohibited Places Generally. Except when necessary to avoid conflict
with other traffic or to protect the safety of any person or vehicle or in
compliance with law or the directions of a police officer or official traffic
control device, no person shall:
      (1)   Stop, stand or park a vehicle:
         A.   On a sidewalk or the area between the curb or curbline and the
sidewalk;
         B.   Within an intersection;
         C.   On a crosswalk;
         D.   Alongside or opposite any street excavation or obstruction when
stopping, standing or parking would obstruct traffic;
         E.   Upon any bridge or viaduct;
         F.   On any railroad tracks;
         G.   In the area between roadways of a divided highway; or
         H.   At any place where official signs prohibit stopping.
      (2)   Stand or park a vehicle:
         A.   In front of a public or private driveway;
         B.   Within fifteen feet of a fire hydrant;
         C.   Within twenty feet of a crosswalk at an intersection;
         D.   Within thirty feet upon the approach to any flashing signal;
         E.   Within thirty feet of a stop sign;
         F.   Within thirty feet of a yield sign;
         G.   Within thirty feet of a traffic-control signal located at the
site of a roadway;
         H.   Within twenty feet of the driveway entrance to any fire station;
         I.   Within seventy-five feet of an entrance to a fire station on the
opposite side of the street;
         J.   On a limited-access highway; or
         K.   At any place where official signs prohibit standing.
      (3)   Park a vehicle:
         A.   Within fifty feet of the nearest rail of a railroad crossing; or
         B.   At any place where official signs prohibit parking.
   (b)   Unattended Vehicles on Private Property. No person shall park or leave
unattended a vehicle on private property without the consent of the owner or
other person in control or possession of the property except in the case of
emergency or disablement of the vehicle, in which case the operator shall
arrange for the removal of the vehicle as soon as possible.
   (c)   Property Owner May Remove Vehicle. The owner or other person in charge
or possession of any property on which a vehicle is parked or left unattended
in violation of subsection (b) hereof may remove or have removed the vehicle at
the reasonable expense of the owner of the vehicle.
   (d)   Parking Prohibited During Certain Hours. Parking is prohibited between
the hours of 12:00 a.m. local time and 6:00 a.m. local time on the following
designated streets or portions thereof:
   Agate Way
   Bank Place
   Chestnut Street
   North and South Dock Street
   Franklin Street
   Hickory Street
   N. Irvine between State Street and Ellsworth Avenue
   Main Avenue
   Mill Street
   Pearrell Street
   Penn Avenue
   Pitt Street
   Porter Way
   Railroad Street
   Reno Street
   River Avenue
   Rose Court
   North and South Sharpsville
   Shenango Avenue
   East and West Silver Street
   East and West State Street
   Vine Street
   Yazvac Place
(Ord. 4-78. Passed 2-22-78; Ord. 04-18.  Passed 6-20-18.)
480.09  PARKING ON POSTED STREETS.
   In order to expedite the cleaning of all streets within the corporate limits
of the City, no vehicle shall be parked on any street between the hours of 12:
00 midnight and 10:00 a.m. of the following day where the proper authorities
have posted such streets indicating the temporary prohibition of parking. The
temporary prohibition of parking during the street cleaning process shall be
effective notwithstanding other provisions authorizing parking on such street,
which provisions are temporarily suspended during the period required for
street cleaning purposes in accordance with the provisions of this section.
(Ord. 4-78. Passed 2-22-78.)
480.10  OBSTRUCTING TRAFFIC.
   No vehicles shall be parked so as to obstruct a street crossing, alley or
bus loading zone or in front of any theater or theater exit or on any street or
alley on the school side of the thoroughfare.
(Ord. 4-78. Passed 2-22-78.)
480.11  BUS LOADING AND UNLOADING AREAS AND ZONES.
   (a)   No vehicle shall park in the following areas which are hereby
designated as bus loading zones:
      (1)   East-bound stops on the south side of East State Street:
         A.   100 feet west of Chestnut Street;
         B.   Thirty feet west of South Dock Street.
      (2)   West-bound on East State Street:
         Thirty feet east of the east crosswalk of Chestnut Street on East
State Street.
      (3)   East-bound bus stops on West State Street:
         A.   Thirty feet west of Water Avenue;
         B.   Thirty feet west of the crosswalk at the west end of the State
Street Bridge.
      (4)   West-bound bus stops on West State Street:
         A.   Thirty feet east of Water Avenue;
         B.   Thirty feet west of the crosswalk at the west end of the State
Street Bridge.
      (5)   South-bound bus stops on North Water Avenue:
         Thirty feet north of West State Street.
      (6)   The Chief of Police shall from time to time designate or change the
location of any bus stop.
(Ord. 4-78. Passed 2-22-78.)
   (b)   The following streets or portions thereof shall be marked and
designated as bus loading and unloading zones, and the stopping or standing
thereon by motor vehicles, other than buses, for the purpose of loading or
discharging passengers, is hereby prohibited. The bus loading and unloading
zones shall be:
      (1)   The east side of Vine Avenue commencing at a point twenty feet
north of the intersection of the east line of Vine Street with the north line
of Pitt Street, thence north along the east line of Vine Street to a point
twenty feet south of the intersection of the east line of Vine Street with the
south line of Silver Street; and
      (2)   The east side of Shenango Avenue beginning at a point twenty feet
north of the intersection of the east line of Shenango Avenue with the north
line of State Street, thence north along the east line of Shenango Avenue to a
point, such point being twenty feet south from the intersection of the east
line of Shenango Avenue with the south line of an alley known as Cherry Way.
(Ord. 12-87. Passed 7-22-87.)
480.12  TAXICAB STANDS.
   The Chief of Police shall from time to time designate or change the location
of all taxicab loading areas.
   No vehicle shall be parked in any area designated and restricted as a
taxicab loading station.
(Ord. 4-78. Passed 2-22-78.)
480.13  FIRE LANES.
   (a)   Except as otherwise provided in subsection (b) hereof, no person shall
stop, stand or park a vehicle at any time on any of the following streets or
portions of streets designated as fire lane streets:
   Chestnut Avenue, east and west sides from East Connelly Boulevard to East
State Street.
   Stambaugh Avenue, east side from East Connelly Boulevard to East State
Street.
   Sharon Senior High School Roadway from Linden Street to East State Street on
both sides.
   Roadway at the West Hill Elementary School, both sides of the driveway,
entering on the west most driveway of Ellsworth Street and exiting on the east
most driveway onto Ellsworth Street.
   Roadway at Gamble Elementary School from Hall Avenue in a counterclock- wise
direction and exiting on Hall Avenue on both sides.
   Chestnut Street from Connelly Boulevard to East State Street.
   The driveway-entrance/exit on the west, south and east side of the Municipal
Building, 155 West Connelly Boulevard.
   Sharon City Centre, entire length of the curb in front of the storefronts;
westmost curb facing east.
   A portion of the parking area behind Case Avenue Elementary School,
beginning at the northwest corner of the existing concrete barriers, thence
eastwardly along their total length, with a width northwardly of eight feet.
(Ord. 29-79.  Passed 11-14-79; Ord. 26-80.  Passed 9-10-80; Ord. 3-88. Passed
3-30-88; Ord. 14-94.  Passed 12-20-94.)
   (b)   Notwithstanding the provisions of subsection (a) hereof, parking shall
be allowed on the east side of Chestnut Street 136 feet south from the Wilson
Furniture Company driveway, southern end, to the southern end of the former
Urban League Building.
(Ord. 11-94.  Passed 9-29-94.)
480.14  MAXIMUM PARKING TIME.
   No vehicle shall be parked on any street at one time for more than twenty-
four hours.
(Ord. 4-78.  Passed 2-22-78.)
480.15  LOADING ZONES FOR SCHOOL CHILDREN.
   (a)   No person shall stop, stank or park a vehicle in any area designated
as a school bus loading zone during the prohibited hours or days designated.
   (b)   The following area is hereby designated as a school bus loading zone:
Staumbaugh Avenue on the west side of the street from a point 142 feet south of
the projection of the south curb of Idaho Street to a point 235 feet south of
this projection.
   (c)   No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle in the school bus
loading zone designated in subsection (b) hereof during the hours of 8:00 a.m.
to 9:00 a.m. and 2:00 p.m. to 3:00 p.m. on school days.
(Ord. 25-82.  Passed 11-18-82.)
480.16  ENFORCEMENT.
   (a)   The Chief of Police shall have the authority to establish, for the
sole purpose of enforcing this chapter, a Meter Patrol.  Such Meter Patrol
shall have the right to enforce the provisions of this chapter, as more
specifically set forth hereinafter, and shall have the authority to issue
citations for violations thereof in a manner and form as may be provided by
general law.
   (b)   The Meter Patrol is hereby authorized to enforce the following
sections, subsections and paragraphs: Sections
480.01,
480.02,
480.025,
480.06,
480.07(d),
480.07(e),
480.08(a)(1)A. to F. and H.,
480.08(a)(2)A. to C. and K.,
480.08(a)(3)B.,
480.10,
480.11,
480.13(a) and (c) and
480.14.
   (c)   The Chief of Police shall appoint members to the Meter Patrol after
having first determined that they are citizens of the Commonwealth and of good
character and repute.  Upon the appointment of such members, the Chief of
Police shall certify to the City Clerk the names and addresses of persons so
appointed and they shall be compiled in the office of the City Clerk and open
to public inspection.
   (d)   Members so appointed to the Meter Patrol shall have the right to
enforce this chapter, as hereinbefore more specifically set forth, provided
that they shall, while performing their duties, be dressed in a clearly
identifiable uniform, the same to be determined by the Chief of Police.
   (e)   Members of the Meter Patrol, appointed as hereinbefore provided, need
not be employees of the City, but may be volunteers or employees of any
contractor hired by the City for the purpose of administering the City's
parking program.
(Ord. 17-84.  Passed 10-24-84.)

480.99  PENALTY.
   (a)   Whoever violates Sections
480.01,
480.015,
480.02,
480.025,
480.03,
480.04,
480.05,
480.06,
480.07,
480.08,
480.14,
480.15, or
480.17, shall be fined ten dollars ($10.00) for each violation provided said
fine is paid within 72 hours.  If the fine is not paid within ten days, the
fine for each violation shall be twenty dollars ($20.00).
   (b)   Whoever violates Section
480.13 shall be fined fifty dollars ($50.00) provided said fine is paid within
ten days of the violation, otherwise the fine shall be one hundred dollars
($100.00) per violation.
(Ord. 35-80. Passed 9-10-80; Ord. 19-02. Passed 12-19-02; Ord. 02-03. Passed 2-
20-03.)

482.01  FIFTEEN-MINUTE PARKING METER ZONE. (REPEALED)
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: Section
482.01 was repealed by Ordinance 24-80, passed September 10, 1980.)
482.02  THIRTY-MINUTE PARKING METER ZONE.
   No vehicle shall be parked between the hours of 8:00 a. m. and 9:00 p. m.
during week days, and between the hours of 1:00 p. m. and 9:00 p. m. on
Sundays, in excess of thirty minutes at any one time upon the portions of the
streets hereinafter described and designated as thirty-minute parking zones:
   Bank Street, north side from the alley to South Dock Street.
   South Dock Street, west side from a point 153 feet south of East State
Street an area of eighty-eight feet in length for four meter spaces and an open
space of eighty-eight feet and then an area of sixty-six feet for three meter
spaces.
   North Sharpsville Avenue, east side from East State Street to Pitt Street;
west side from Pitt Street to East Silver Street.
   Vine Avenue, west side from East State Street to Pitt Street.
(Ord. 4-78. Passed 2-22-78; Ord. 30-79. Passed 11-14-79; Ord. 42-80. Passed 12-
10-80.)
482.03  TWO-HOUR PARKING METER ZONE.
   No vehicle shall be parked between the hours of 8:00 a. m. and 9:00 p. m.
during week days, and between the hours of 1:00 p. m. and 9:00 p. m. on
Sundays, in excess of two hours at any one time upon portions of the streets
hereinafter described and designated as two-hour parking meter zones:
   Penn Avenue, west side from Pearrel Drive to Rose Court.
   Reno Street, north side from Shenango Street to North Railroad Street.
   Shenango Street, east side from Central Way to East Silver Street.
   Vine Avenue, west side from Pitt Street to Reno Street.
   North Main Street between West State Street and West Silver Street.
(Ord. 4-78. Passed 2-22-78; Ord. 43-80. Passed 12-10-80.)
482.04  TEN-HOUR PARKING METER ZONE.
   No vehicle shall be parked between the hours of 8:00 a. m. and 9:00 p. m.
during week days, and between the hours of 1:00 p.m. and 9:00 p.m. on Sundays,
in excess of ten hours at any one time upon portions of the streets hereinafter
described and designated as ten-hour parking meter zones:
   North Sharpsville Avenue, both sides from East Silver Street to Hull Street;
west side from Hull Street to Thornton Avenue.
(Ord. 4-78. Passed 2-22-78.)
482.05  OFF-STREET PARKING METER ZONES.
   No vehicle shall be parked between the hours of 8:00 a. m. and 9:00 p. m. on
week days, and between the hours of 1:00 p.m. and 9:00 p.m. on Sundays, in
excess of five hours at any one time upon portions of the off-street parking
system and Sites No. 1, 2, 4 and 5, or in excess of two hours at any one time
upon portions of the off-street parking system and Site 3. Such Sites are off-
street parking meter zones, designated and described as follows:
   (a)   Site No. 1 shall be known and designated as the Elk's Site and is
described as follows: Beginning at the southwest corner of the intersection of
East Silver Street and Shenango Avenue; being bounded on the east by Shenango
Avenue a distance of 145.51 feet; on the south by other lands of B. P.O.E.,
Lodge No. 103, a distance of 115.0 feet; on the west by River Avenue a distance
of 114.25 feet; thence in a northeasterly direction along the lands of the
Standard Oil Company a distance of 50.0 feet; thence along the south line of
East Silver Street a distance of 115.0 feet.
   (b)   Site No. 2 shall be known and designated as the Penn-Shenango Site and
is described as follows:
      (1)   Tract No. 1: Beginning at the point at the northeast intersection
of Penn Avenue and East Silver Street; thence along the east line of Penn
Avenue a distance of 150.0 feet; thence along the south line of the lands of
General State Authority (Pennsylvania State University) a distance of 135.5
feet; thence along the west line of an unnamed alley a distance of 148.55 feet;
thence westerly along the north line of East Silver Street a distance of 115.0
feet.
      (2)   Tract No. 2: Beginning at a point at the northwest intersection of
Shenango Avenue and East Silver Street; thence along the north line of East
Silver Street a distance of 111.0 feet; thence in a northerly direction along
the east line of an unnamed alley a distance of 100.0 feet; thence along the
south line of lands of Thomas E. Alverson a distance of 108.0 feet more or
less; thence along the west line of Shenango Avenue a distance of 100.0 feet.
   (c)   Site No. 3 shall be known and designated as the Pitt-Vine Site and is
described as follows: Beginning at the northwest corner of Pitt Street and Vine
Avenue; being bound on the south by the north line of Pitt Street a distance of
79.5 feet; thence northerly along the east line of lands of the Tastee Bakery a
distance of 57.0 feet; thence in an easterly direction along the south line of
the lands of Valley Tastee Bakery a distance of 79.5 feet to the west line of
Vine Avenue; thence southerly a distance of 57.0 feet to the point at the place
of beginning.
   (d)   Site No. 4 shall be known and designated as the Hull Street Site and
is described as follows: Beginning at the northwest corner of Hull Street and
North Sharpsville Avenue; being bounded on the west by the east line of North
Sharpsville Avenue a distance of 66.0 feet; thence easterly along the south
edge of an unnamed alley a distance of 124.0 feet; thence southerly along the
west line of an unnamed alley a distance of 66.0 feet; thence westerly along
the north line of Hull Street a distance of 124.0 feet to the point at the
place of beginning.
   (e)   Site No. 5 shall be known and designated as the Library Site and is
described as follows:
      (1)   Tract No. 1: Upper level of the Library Site with entrance from
North Sharpsville Avenue.
      (2)   Tract No. 2: Lower level of the Library Site with entrances and
exits on Pitt Street and North Dock Street.
   The Library Site is part of the property of the City of Sharon, known and
designated as the Buhl-Henderson Community Library, and is described as
follows: Beginning at the southeast corner of North Dock Street and Pitt
Street; being bounded on the north by the south line of Pitt Street a distance
of 206.6 feet; thence southerly along the west line of North Sharpsville Avenue
a distance of 277.13 feet; thence westerly along the north line of East State
Street a distance of 128.28 feet; thence northerly along the east line of North
Dock Street a distance of 261.33 feet to the point at the place of beginning.
(Ord. 4-78. Passed 2-22-78; Ord. 16-81. Passed 6-24-81.)
482.06  OFF-STREET CASHIER-CONTROLLED ZONES.
   The following sites shall be cashier-controlled parking sites. They shall be
in operation daily, Sunday through Saturday, from 7:30 a.m. to 9:30 p.m.
   Site No. 6 shall be known and designated as the Hospital Site and is
described as follows: Beginning at a point 150.0 feet north of East State
Street and Ormond Avenue on the east line of Ormond Avenue a distance of 150

along the south line of such lands of Andrew Butchko, et al, a distance of
142.0 feet; thence southerly along the west line of Jefferson Avenue a distance
of 161.66 feet; thence westerly along the north line of lands of Hugh Garvey a
