line of lands of Hugh Garvey, Patience Garvey and Vacuum Oil Co. , Inc. , to
the north line of East State Street; thence westerly along the north line of
East State Street a distance of 71.0 feet; thence northerly along lines of
lands of Rose Mazzola and Thomas Scraggs-Ronald and Lois Brennan a distance of
150.0 feet; thence westerly along the north line of lands of Thomas Scraggs-
Ronald and Lois Brennan and J. Bradley McGonigle a distance of 155.0 feet to
the point at the place of beginning.
(Ord. 4-78. Passed 2-22-78; Ord. 29-80. Passed 9-10-80.)
482.065  OFF-STREET CONTROLLED ZONES.
   The following sites shall be controlled parking site and shall be in
operation daily, Monday through Friday, from 7:30 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. , except
during those periods of time when the same shall be designated for use by the
Mayor, at which time the lot shall open at 6:00 a. m. Parking shall be limited
to a period of two hours, except after 5:00 p.m., Monday through Friday, and
Saturdays, Sundays and holidays, when it shall be unlimited.
   (a)   Site No. 7 shall be known and designated as the Chestnut Street Site
and is described as follows: Beginning at the southwest corner of Connelly
Boulevard and South Railroad Street; bounded on the east by the west line of
South Railroad Street in a northerly direction a distance of 294.0 feet; thence
westerly along the south line of lands of J. M. Willson a distance of 105.0
feet then continuing westerly a distance of 10.0 feet across an unnamed vacated
alley to a point 302.07 feet north of the north line of Connelly Boulevard;
thence southerly along the east line of lands of J. M. Willson and Sons, Inc. ,
and R. Radick a distance of 123.74 feet; thence westerly along the south edge
of such lands of R. Radick a distance of 106.67 feet to Chestnut Street; thence
southerly along the east line of Chestnut Street a distance of 128.33 feet;
thence easterly along the north line of other lands of R. Radick a distance of
129.65 feet; thence southerly a distance of 50.0 feet along the east line of
such lands of R. Radick to Connelly Boulevard a distance of 98.87 feet to the
point of beginning.
   (b)   Site No. 8 shall be known and designated as the Water Avenue Site and
is described as follows: Beginning at the southeast intersection of West Silver
Street and North Water Avenue; thence in an easterly direction along the south
line of West Silver Street a distance of 168 feet more or less; thence along
the west line of the Shenango River a distance of 201.0 feet more or less;
thence in a southerly direction along the west line of Porter Way a distance of
79.0 feet; thence in a westerly direction along the north line of lands of C.
K. M. Corporation a distance of 108 feet more or less; thence in a southerly
direction along the west line of such lands of C. K. M. Corporation a distance
of 123 feet more or less; thence westerly along the north line of a private
alley on lands of Stephen Wasilewski and N. Lustig a distance of 48.0 feet;
thence westerly an additional 5.0 feet at the southern terminus of a vacated
unnamed alley along the east line of lands of S. Leftheris; thence in a
northerly direction along the centerline of such vacated unnamed alley a
distance of 40.0 feet; thence northerly an additional 4.0 feet at the eastern
terminus of an unnamed alley on the north line of such lands of S. Leftheris;
thence westerly along the centerline of such vacated unnamed alley a distance
of 80 feet more or less to the east line of North Water Avenue; thence in a
northerly direction along the east line of North Water Avenue a distance of
250.0 feet to the point at the place of beginning.
(Ord. 30-80. Passed 9-10-80.)
482.07  MULTI-LEVEL PARKING GARAGE.
   (a)   The following sites shall be known and designated as multi-level
parking garages and shall be in operation from 7:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m., Monday
through Friday.
   (b)   Site No. 9 shall be known and designated as the Multi-Level Garage and
is described as follows:
      (1)   Beginning at the southwest corner of the intersection of Pitt
Street and North Railroad Street; being bounded on the east by North Railroad
Street a distance of 232.5 feet; thence in a westerly direction along the south
line of East Silver Street a distance of 190.33 feet; thence in a southerly
direction along the east line of Vine Avenue a distance of 233.0 feet; thence
in an easterly direction along the north line of Pitt Street a distance of
158.0 feet to the point at the place of beginning.
      (2)   It is a five-level garage.
   (c)   All persons parking their cars in the multi-level garage during the
period of free operation shall cause their cars to be removed before 5:00 a.m.
each weekday.
   (d)   Each monthly parker shall register with the Bureau of Traffic and
Parking, the registration plate of the car, along with the make of the car.
Only registered cars will be permitted to park from 7:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m.,
Monday through Friday.
   (e)   Any car parked in violation of any provision of this section shall be
in violation of this Traffic Code and subject to a citation.
(Ord. 4-78. Passed 2-22-78; Ord. 31-80. Passed 9-10-80.)
482.08  PARKING SPACES AND METERS.
   The proper officers of the City shall provide all parking meter zones with
appropriate parking spaces and shall erect in such places a parking meter
which, upon the deposit of the proper coin, will indicate the duration of the
legal parking period and the time when such period elapsed.
(Ord. 4-78. Passed 2-22-78.)
482.09  REQUIRED DEPOSIT.
   The operator of any vehicle shall deposit, upon entering a parking meter
zone, a coin of the United States at the rate of ten cents (100 for each
thirty-minute period in the parking meter designated for the appropriate
parking space, except as otherwise specified in this chapter.
(Ord. 10-85. Passed 7-2-85.)
482.10  REQUIRED DEPOSIT; THIRTY-MINUTE ZONES. (REPEALED)
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: Section
482.10 was repealed, by implication, by Ordinance 10-85, passed July 2, 1985.)
482.11  REQUIRED DEPOSIT; TWO-HOUR ZONES. (REPEALED)
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: Section
482.11 was repealed, by implication, by Ordinance 10-85, passed July 2, 1985.)
482.12  REQUIRED DEPOSIT; TEN-HOUR ZONES. (REPEALED)
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: Section
482.12 was repealed, by implication, by Ordinance 10-85, passed July 2, 1985.)
482.13  REQUIRED DEPOSIT; OFF-STREET SITES.
   (a)   The operator of any vehicle shall deposit, upon entering off-street
parking meter zone Site Nos. 1 and 5, a coin of the United States at the rate
of five cents ($0.05) for each one-half hour period, and upon entering off-
street parking meter zone Site No. 2, a coin of the United States at the rate
of ten cents ($0.10) for each one-hour period, and upon entering Site No. 4, a
coin of the United States at the rate of ten cents ($0.10) for a one-hour
period, and upon entering off-street meter zone Site No. 3, a coin of the
United States at the rate of ten cents ($0.10) for each one-half hour period,
in the parking meter designated for the appropriate parking space.
(Ord. 4-78. Passed 2-22-78.)
   (b)   The operator of a vehicle may purchase from the Mayor or his
designated representative permits at Site No. 5 at the rate of twelve dollars
($12.00) per month.
(Ord. 20-79. Passed 8-16-79.)
   (c)   The deposit of five cents ($0.05) for each half hour period in Site
No. 5, Tracts 1 and 2, is not required Monday through Friday during the hours
of 12:00 noon and 2:00 p.m.
(Ord. 37-80. Passed 10-1-80.)
482.14  CASHIER-CONTROLLED OFF-STREET SITES; REQUIRED PAYMENT.
   The operator of any vehicle shall pay to the cashier, upon leaving a
cashier-controlled Site No. 6, 7 or 9, at the rate of twenty-five cents ($0.25)
for the first half-hour, twenty-five cents ($0.25) for the second half-hour and
twenty-five cents ($.25) for each additional hour, but not to exceed a rate of
two dollars ($2.00) for an eight-hour period or more.
   (a)   The operator of any vehicle may present to the cashier a City of
Sharon Parking Authority Validating Sticker at the rate of two stamps for each
one hour of parking or one stamp and ten cents (104) for a like period.
   (b)   Upon closing of the cashier-controlled site, the cashier shall place
upon any vehicle remaining on the site an envelope requiring the operator of
the vehicle, upon exiting the site, to place therein fifty cents ($0.50) in
coins of the United States. The envelope shall note the registration number of
the vehicle, the description of the vehicle and the date and time of the use of
the site.
      (1)   The cashier shall record daily all such vehicles recording all
vehicles whose owner or operator complies with subsection (b) hereof and those
that fail to do so within forty-eight hours after the use of the parking site.
      (2)   The Parking Authority shall report to the Bureau of Police all
vehicles whose owner or operator fails to make the necessary envelope payment.
   (c)   The operator of a vehicle may purchase permits from the City of Sharon
Bureau of Traffic and Parking at the following rates:
      (1)   The weekly rates for Site No. 6 shall be five dollars ($5.00).
      (2)   The monthly rates for Site Nos. 6 and 9 shall be twelve dollars
($12.00).
      (3)   In Site No. 6, a visitor to the Sharon General Hospital may
purchase a weekly permit at the rate of four dollars ($4.00) renewable up to
and including three weeks.
         A.   The weekly rate for a visitor may not be applied to the purchase
of a monthly pass.
         B.   After the third week of the visitor's permit has passed, one week
must pass before the visitor may again purchase the reduced permit.
   (d)   Council authorizes the following discount schedule for parking
validations on a per year basis:
      Regular price   $14.00
      Groups of 10 through 20   13.00
      Groups of 21 through 30   12.00
      Groups of 31 and above   10.00
      Validation stamps will be sold to merchants at fifteen cents ($0.15)
each. Each stamp allows one hour free parking with a two-hour maximum.
(Ord. 4-78. Passed 2-22-78; Ord. 14-79. Passed 7-13-79; Ord. 32-80. Passed 9-
10-80; Ord. 1$-84. Passed 11-20-84; Ord. 9-85. Passed 7-2-85; Res. 41-86.
Passed 3-26-86.)
482.145  MONTHLY PARKING AT SITES 1, 2 AND 8.
   The Director of the Bureau of Traffic and Parking shall have the authority
to rent monthly parking spaces in Site No. 1 (Elks); Site No. 2 (Penn-Shenango:
Tract land 2) and Site No. 8 (Water Avenue) under special circumstances, but
shall be limited to ten percent of the total spaces of each site.
   The monthly rate shall be twelve dollars ($12.00).
(Ord. 47-80. Passed 11-12-80.)
482.15  COUNTERFEIT COINS; SLUGS.
   No person shall deposit or cause to be deposited in any parking meter, a
slug, device or metallic substitute for a United States coin.
(Ord. 4-78. Passed 2-22-78.)
482.16  TAMPERING WITH METERS AND TRAFFIC SIGNS.
   No person shall deface, tamper with, damage, open or willfully break,
destroy or impair the usefulness of any parking meter, traffic sign or street
designation sign.
(Ord. 4-78. Passed 2-22-78.)
482.17  USE OF OFF-STREET SITES; ENTRANCE, EXIT.
   All motor vehicle traffic entering or leaving any of the off-street parking
sites shall enter such areas at the points designated by proper signs for such
entrance and shall leave such areas at the points designated as exits.
(Ord. 4-78. Passed 2-22-78.)
482.18  USE OF OFF-STREET SITES; PARKING SPACES.
   (a)   All motor vehicles entering the parking spaces on the off-street
parking sites shall utilize only the space designated by the proper parking
meter and shall be parked with the front portion thereof facing the parking
meter and shall not be parked so as to occupy more than one designated parking
space.
   (b)   All motor vehicles entering parking spaces in the off-street
controlled sites shall utilize only the space designated for proper parking and
shall not be parked so as to occupy more than one designated parking space.
(Ord. 28-80. Passed 9-10-80.)
482.19  USE OF OFF-STREET SITES; PARKING POSITION.
   No operator of a motor vehicle shall park in any of the spaces designated
for parking in off-street parking sites by placing such motor vehicle in such a
parking space so that the rear end thereof faces the parking meter provided for
such parking space.
(Ord. 4-78.  Passed 2-22-78.)
482.20  USE OF OFF-STREET SITES; PARKING IN DRIVEWAYS.
   No operator of a motor vehicle entering any of the off-street parking sites
shall park such motor vehicle in any of the areas provided for means of egress
or ingress in such areas or any of the driveways provided therein for the
movement of traffic in and through such parking sites.
(Ord. 4-78.  Passed 2-22-78.)
482.21  USE OF RESERVED MONTHLY OR WEEKLY PARKING SPACES.
   No operator of a motor vehicle entering any of the off-street parking sites
shall park such motor vehicle in a reserved weekly or monthly parking space.
   The Director of the Bureau of Traffic and Parking shall properly designate
reserved weekly and monthly parking spaces.
(Ord. 34-80.  Passed 9-10-80.)
482.22  ENFORCEMENT.
   (a)   The Chief of Police shall have the authority to establish, for the
sole purpose of enforcing this chapter, a Meter Patrol. Such Meter Patrol shall
have the right to enforce the provisions of this chapter, as more specifically
set forth hereinafter, and shall have the authority to issue citations for
violations thereof in a manner and form as may be provided by general law.
   (b)   The Meter Patrol is hereby authorized to enforce the following
sections, subsections and paragraphs: Sections
482.02,
482.03,
482.04,
482.05(a) to (c) and (e),
482.06,
482.065(a),
482.07,
482.08,
482.09,
482.10,
482.11,
482.12,
482.13,
482.14,
482.145,
482.18,
482.19,
482.20 and
482.21.
   (c)   The Chief of Police shall appoint members to the Meter Patrol after
having first determined that they are citizens of the Commonwealth and of good
character and repute. Upon the appointment of such members the Chief of Police
shall certify to the City Clerk the names and addresses of persons so appointed
and they shall be compiled in the office of the City Clerk and open to public
inspection.
   (d)   Members so appointed to the Meter Patrol shall have the right to
enforce this chapter, as hereinbefore more specifically set forth, provided
that they shall, while performing their duties, be dressed in a clearly
identifiable uniform, the same to be determined by the Chief of Police.
   (e)   Members of the Meter Patrol, appointed as hereinbefore provided, need
not be employees of the City, but may be volunteers or employees of any
contractor hired by the City for the purpose of administering the City's
parking program.
(Ord. 17-84. Passed 10-24-84.)
482.23  AMENDMENT OF PARKING FEES AND CHARGES.
   Council may, by resolution, periodically amend the fees and charges for
parking as set forth in this chapter. Said resolution will be effective in
accordance with the terms thereof, provided that a copy of the resolution will
be on display in the office of the City Clerk and shall be made available to
all persons requesting same upon the payment of reasonable costs of
reproduction.
(Ord. 8-90. Passed 8-22-90.)
482.24  TWO-HOUR OFF-STREET LOT.
   Between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 10:00 p.m., no vehicle shall park for
more than two consecutive hours in the off-street lot located at the corner of
East State Street and South Sharpsville Ave.
(Ord. 60-04.  Passed 9-16-04.)
482.99  PENALTY.
   (a)   Whoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of
Sections
482.01 through
482.06 and Sections
482.08 through
482.14 shall be fined not less than five dollars ($5.00), except that any
person may discharge the penalty under these sections by depositing the notice
of violation together with the sum of one dollar ($1.00) within forty-eight
hours subsequent to such violation at the main office of the Bureau of Police
in the Municipal Building or in any violation receptacle placed upon the off-
street parking lots or other convenient places in the City.
(Ord. 11-85. Passed 7-2-85.)
   (b)   Whoever violates Section
482.15 or
482.16 shall be fined not less than one dollar ($1.00) nor more than three
hundred dollars ($300.00).
   (c)   Whoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of
Sections
482.17 through
482.20 shall be fined not less than two dollars ($2.00) nor more than fifteen
dollars ($15.00).
   (d)   Whoever violates or fails to comply with Section
482.14(b)(1) or (2) may discharge his payment by depositing the required
payment within forty-eight hours. After forty-eight hours, the payment shall be
not less than two dollars ($2.00) nor more than fifteen dollars ($15.00).
   (e)   Whoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of
Sections
482.065 and
482.07 shall be fined not less than five dollars ($5.00) nor more than fifteen
dollars ($15.00).
   (f)   Whoever violates Section
482.21 shall be fined not less than five dollars ($5.00) nor more than fifteen
dollars ($15.00).
(Ord. 36-80. Passed 9-10-80.)

CHAPTER 602
Alcoholic Beverages
602.01   Definitions.
602.02   Consumption on public or private property.
602.03   Open containers on public or private property.
602.04   Discarding of alcoholic beverages, containers and wrappers.
602.05   Exceptions.
 
602.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Contraband in correctional institutions - see Crimes Code Sec. 5123
   Public drunkenness - see Crimes Code Sec. 5505
   Misrepresentation of age to secure liquor - see Crimes Code Secs. 6307 et
seq.
   Sale of solidified alcohol - see Crimes Code Sec. 7302
   Public eating and drinking places - see B.R. & T. Ch.
828
602.01  DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter, unless the context requires otherwise:
   (a)   "Alcoholic beverage" means any spirits, wine, beer, ale or other
liquid containing more than one-half of one percent of alcohol by volume which
is fit for consumption as a beverage.
   (b)   "Container" means any bottle, can or other vessel in which alcoholic
beverages are contained.
   (c)   "Wrapper" means any box, carton, paper or other material enclosing a
container.
(Ord. 14-92. Passed 8-26-92.)
602.02  CONSUMPTION ON PUBLIC OR PRIVATE PROPERTY.
   No person shall consume alcoholic beverages in any quantity upon any street,
avenue, alley, sidewalk, stairway, thoroughfare or other public property within
the City, nor shall any person consume any alcoholic beverage within five feet
of any public way or thoroughfare while on a private stairway, doorway or other
private property open to public view without the express or implied permission
of the owner, his or her agent or other party in lawful possession thereof.
(Ord. 14-92. Passed 8-26-92.)
602.03  OPEN CONTAINERS ON PUBLIC OR PRIVATE PROPERTY.
   No person shall possess any alcoholic beverage container, whether wrapped or
unwrapped, which has been opened or on which the seal has been broken in any
manner, on any public street, avenue, alley, thoroughfare or other public
property within the City, nor shall any person possess any alcoholic beverage
container, whether wrapped or unwrapped, which has been opened or on which the
seal has been broken in any manner, within five feet of any public way or
thoroughfare while on a private stairway, doorway or other private property
open to public view without the express or implied permission of the owner, his
or her agent or other person in lawful possession thereof.
(Ord. 14-92. Passed 8-26-92.)
602.04  DISCARDING OF ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES, CONTAINERS AND WRAPPERS.
   No person shall discard any alcoholic beverage, container or wrapper upon
any public street, avenue, alley, thoroughfare or other public property within
the City, nor shall any person discard any alcoholic beverage, container or
wrapper within five feet of any public way or thoroughfare while on a private
stairway, doorway or other private property open to public view without the
express or implied permission of the owner, his or her agent or other person in
lawful possession thereof.
(Ord. 14-92. Passed 8-26-92.)
602.05  EXCEPTIONS.
   The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to interior portions of any
private dwelling, habitat or building, nor to the consumption or discarding by
persons in the areas herein designated of any duly prescribed and dispensed
medication having alcoholic content as defined in Section
602.01(a). Further, the provisions of this chapter shall not apply to premises
duly licensed by the Pennsylvania Liquor Control Board, nor to persons who are
then and there patrons of such licensee.
(Ord. 14-92. Passed 8-26-92.)
602.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any of the provisions of this chapter shall be fined not
less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than three hundred dollars
($300.00), together with costs, and, in default of payment of such fine and
costs, shall be imprisoned for a period not to exceed sixty days.
(Ord. 14-92. Passed 8-26-92.)
CHAPTER 604
Animals
604.01   Short title.
604.02   Purpose and intent.
604.03   Intermunicipal agreement.
604.04   Definitions.

604.08   Impoundment, redemption and disposition.
604.09   Confinement of dogs.
604.10   Rabies; vaccination.
604.11   Seeing-eye dogs.
604.12   Dog biting.

604.14   Nuisances.
604.15   Standards of care.
604.16   Stray cats.
604.17   Notice of violation.
604.18   Enforcement.
 
604.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Animals on sidewalks and private property - see GEN. OFF.
660.04
   Manure; containers - see GEN. OFF.
664.12
   Proximity of animals to dwelling houses - see GEN. OFF.
664.13
   Disposal of carcasses - see GEN. OFF.
664.15
   Private shelters for domestic pets in R-1 Districts - see P. & Z. 1248.02(b)
(3)
604.01  SHORT TITLE.
   This chapter shall be known and may be cited as the Shenango Valley Dog
Ordinance.
(Ord. 38-66. Passed 11-9-66.)
604.02  PURPOSE AND INTENT.
   It is the purpose and intent of this chapter, under the authority granted to
the participating municipalities by their respective codes, the Municipal
Cooperation Act of May 21, 1943 (P. L. 340), as amended, and the Dog Law of
1965, to establish and to provide for the following:
   (a)   Regulating the keeping of dogs;
   (b)   Prohibiting the running at large of dogs;
   (c)   Impounding and destruction of dogs found running at large;
   (d)   Quarantining of dogs in heat and/or suspected of rabies;
   (e)   Rabies vaccination; and
   (f)   Such other rules and regulations necessary for the control of dogs
running at large and to promote public health and public welfare in the
communities.
(Ord. 38-66. Passed 11-9-66.)
604.03  INTERMUNICIPAL AGREEMENT.
   (EDITOR’S NOTE: Former Section 604.03 Administration, based on Ord. 38-66,
passed November 9, 1966, was repealed October 19, 2017, by Ord. 10-17.)
   An intermunicipal agreement for cooperation with the other participating
municipalities shall be entered into for the operation of an animal control
shelter and related animal control needs, and said agreement shall be made in
accordance with Pennsylvania law governing such agreements, 53 Pa.C.S. § 2301,
et seq., to the extent that said law would be applicable to this agreement.
(Ord. 11-17.  Passed 10-19-17.)
604.04  DEFINITIONS.
   For the purposes of this chapter, the following terms shall, unless the
context indicates otherwise, have the meanings ascribed to them:
   (a)   "Board" means the Shenango Valley Animal Control Board.
   (b)   "Executive Director" means the chief administrative officer of the
Shenango Valley Animal Control Board.
   (c)   "Animal Shelter" means the facilities from which the Shenango Valley
Animal Control Board operates to enforce the Shenango Valley Dog Ordinance.
   (d)   "Dog Law of 1965" means Act 437 of December 22, 1965, governing the
State's role in animal control.
   (e)   "Animal Warden" means a person or persons employed by the Shenango
Valley Animal Control Board as its enforcement officer and/or shelter operator.
   (f)   "At large" means any dog which is off the property of its owner and
not under the immediate control of a competent person.
   (g)   "Restraint" means controlled by a leash, at "heel" beside a competent
person and obedient to that person's commands, on or within a vehicle being
driven or parked on the streets or within the property limits of the owner or
keeper of a dog.
   (h)   "Owner" means any person who has a right of property in such dog; who
owns, harbors, keeps or causes or permits to be harbored or kept or has in his
care a dog on or about any premises occupied by him.
   (i)   "Kennel" means any establishment wherein dogs are kept for the
purposes of breeding, boarding, sale or show, and from which the dog cannot
stray.
   (j)   "Officer" means any person employed or elected by the Commonwealth, a
political subdivision or the Animal Control Board, whose duty it is to preserve
peace, make arrests or enforce the Dog Law of 1965 and/or this chapter.
   (k)   "Person" means any individual, corporation, partnership, association
or State or local officer or employee.
   (l)   "Veterinarian" means a doctor of veterinary medicine who holds a valid
license to practice his profession.
   (m)   "Collar" means a band, chain, harness or other suitable device worn
around the neck of a dog to which a current rabies vaccination-registration tag
and a license tag can be affixed.
   (n)   "Vaccination" means the inoculation of a dog with a vaccine that is
licensed by the United States Department of Agriculture and which is
administered by a veterinarian for the purpose of immunizing the dog against
rabies.
   (o)   "Exposed to rabies" means a dog which has been bitten by any other
animal or which has been in contact with any animal known to be, or suspected
of being, infected with rabies.
   (p)   "Bite" means any abrasion, scratch, puncture, tear or piercing of the
skin actually or suspected of being caused by a dog.
   (q)   "Shenango Valley" means the City of Farrell, the Township of Hickory,
the City of Sharon, the Borough of Sharpsville, the Borough of Wheatland and
such other municipalities as may hereafter become participating members of the
Shenango Valley Animal Control Board.
(Ord. 38-66. Passed 11-9-66.)
604.05  CENSUS OF DOGS.
   The Animal Warden and/or such other person as may be designated by the Board
may, after January 15, or as soon thereafter as possible of this year and
annually hereafter, cause a census to be made of all dogs owned, kept, harbored
or cared for within the territorial limits of Shenango Valley and shall
complete such records as are necessary to set forth the names and addresses of
all persons owning, keeping, harboring or caring for such dogs, the number of
licensed dogs owned by such persons, together with the license number and
record of rabies vaccination of any dogs, and the number of unlicensed dogs
owned, kept, harbored or cared for by any person, together with a complete
description of each of such licensed or unlicensed dogs and any other data
necessary for promoting animal control for the public good.
(Ord. 38-66. Passed 11-9-66.)
604.06  DOGS AT LARGE.
   Any person who owns, keeps, harbors or cares for a dog is subject to a
notice of violation and penalty, or the impoundment of the dog, or both, if the
dog is permitted to be at large. A dog will be considered at large in the
following instances:
   (a)   All Dogs. Any dog that is off the property of the owner or the person
keeping or harboring him, unless such dog is on a leash, at "heel" beside a
competent person and obedient to that person's command, under the immediate
control of a competent person, or otherwise humanely restrained, will be
considered at large.
   (b)   School Grounds and Recreation Areas. Any dog that is upon any school
premises or grounds or upon any public recreation area when an organized
activity is being conducted, unless the dog is controlled by a leash or similar
device, will be considered at large.
   (c)   Public Places. Any dog, whether on leash or not, which is or which
enters upon any church premises, public meeting or gathering place, restaurant,
food market, eating establishment, department or dry goods store and rest room
open to the public during the time that such place is open for business, will
be considered at large. However, these provisions do not apply to dogs leading
visually handicapped persons.
   (d)   Muzzling Vicious Dogs. Any dog of fierce, dangerous or vicious
propensity off the property of the owner or the person keeping or harboring
such dog, unless the dog is wearing a muzzle of sufficient strength to prevent
its biting any person or another animal, will be considered at large. The
muzzle shall be worn even though the dog is controlled by a leash, at "heel"
beside a competent person and obedient to that person's command, under the
immediate control of a competent person or otherwise humanely restrained.
(Ord. 38-66. Passed 11-9-66.)
604.07  NOTICE TO OWNER OF IMPOUNDMENT OF DOGS.
   The Animal Warden or his duly authorized representative shall, immediately
upon impounding any dog, make a complete registry, entering the breed, color
and sex of such dog and whether licensed, if known, and if licensed, the name
and address of the owner and the number of the license tag, if known, and if
bearing an inoculation tag, the number of such tag. When any licensed animal is
impounded, the Animal Warden or his duly authorized representative shall give
immediate notice, either personal or by certified mail, to the owner of such
licensed dog, informing such owner of the impounding of his dog and the reason
therefor.
(Ord. 38-66. Passed 11-9-66.)
604.08  IMPOUNDMENT, REDEMPTION AND DISPOSITION.
   (a)   Unlicensed Dogs. The owner shall be entitled to resume possession of
any impounded unlicensed dog upon payment of the at-large penalties or the
impoundment penalties, or both, upon payment of the daily board fees, and upon
compliance with the rabies vaccination and licensing requirements, provided
that application for such possession, with payment of all required penalties
and fees, is made within seventy-two hours after impoundment.
   (b)   Licensed Dogs. The owner shall be entitled to resume possession of any
impounded licensed dog upon payment of at-large penalties or impoundment
penalties, or both, upon payment of the daily board fees, and upon compliance
with rabies vaccination requirements, provided that application for such
possession, with payment of all required penalties and fees, is made within ten
days after impoundment and notice thereof pursuant to the requirements of the
Dog Law of 1965.
   (c)   Disposition of Dogs. Any unlicensed dog impounded and not reclaimed by
the owner after being held at least seventy-two hours after impoundment and any
licensed dog impounded and not reclaimed by the owner after being held ten days
after impoundment and notice, as required by subsection (b) hereof, may be
destroyed in some humane manner.
   (d)   Adoption Authorized. If the Animal Warden or his duly authorized
representative determines that any unclaimed dog is reasonably healthy,
currently vaccinated against rabies and should not constitute a threat to the
public health or welfare of the Shenango Valley, the Animal Warden may retain
such dog for a reasonable period of time to attempt to put the animal up for
adoption.
   (e)   Injured or Ill Animals. Any animal detained and/or impounded and
suffering from serious injuries, in great pain with probability of recovery
remote or having a communicable or infectious disease which would endanger the
health of people or other animals, may be destroyed in a humane manner after
reasonable efforts to determine ownership have failed.
   (f)   Written Release. Any licensed dog may be destroyed in some humane
manner or put up for adoption any time within ten days from the date of
impoundment if, upon notification of impoundment of such dog, the owner states
that he does not wish to redeem the impounded dog and subsequently, in writing,
releases the dog to the sole jurisdiction of the Board.
(Ord. 38-66. Passed 11-9-66.)
604.09  CONFINEMENT OF DOGS.
   (a)   Vicious Dogs. Dogs of fierce, dangerous or vicious propensity, whether
licensed or not, shall not be allowed to run at large upon the premises of one
other than the owner's. If any such dog is found running at large in violation
of this provision, it shall be taken up and impounded and shall not be released
except upon the approval of the Animal Warden after payment of the penalties.
However, if any dangerous, fierce or vicious dog so found at large cannot be
safely taken and impounded, such dog may be destroyed by a duly authorized
representative of the Shenango Valley Animal Control Board.
   (b)   Securing Vicious Dogs. Dogs of fierce, dangerous or vicious
propensity, when on the property of the owner or of a person keeping or
harboring such dog, shall be secured in such a way that the dog cannot reach
mailmen, delivery personnel, newspaper boys or any others who may have occasion
to enter the owner's premises in the course of their work.
   (c)   Dogs in Heat. Female dogs in heat shall be confined by the owner in a
closed building so that the dog cannot come into contact with another except
for planned breeding.
(Ord. 38-66. Passed 11-9-66.)
   (d)   Suspected Rabies Case. Dogs suspected of rabies shall be confined by
the owner in and at a place designated by the Animal Warden or his duly
authorized representative at the owner's expense, in such a way as to prohibit
such rabies suspected dog from coming into contact with any other animal or
person and/or from escaping. Such rabies-suspected dog shall be confined until
such time as a veterinarian has authorized in writing its release or
nonconfinement. The veterinarian's examination must be made between the tenth
and fifteenth day after the date the dog bite occurred.
(Ord. 12-77. Passed 5-11-77. )
604.10  RABIES; VACCINATION.
   (a)   Current Vaccination. No person shall own, keep, harbor, care for or
have on or about the premises occupied by such person within the Shenango
Valley any dog six months of age or older unless such dog has a current rabies
vaccination. A dog will have a current vaccination for the remainder of the
month during which it was vaccinated and for the following twelve calendar
months, if injected with a dead virus, and/or for the following thirty-six
calendar months, if injected with a live virus vaccine. The dog must be re-
vaccinated before the expiration of the first and each subsequent current
vaccination period.
   (b)   Exception. Vaccination will not be required of any dog when a
certificate from a veterinarian that such dog should not be inoculated with
rabies vaccine and the valid medical reasons therefor have been filed with the
Board at the Animal Shelter.
   (c)   Registration. No owner shall have, within the Shenango Valley, any dog
six months of age or older unless such dog is currently vaccine-registered with
the Board. No dog shall be registered unless it has a current vaccination or an
exemption under subsection (b) hereof.
   (d)   Vaccination Tag. A registration shall be considered as being current
for the period of the current vaccination for which it was issued. A
vaccination-registration certificate and tag may be obtained at the time of
vaccination from veterinarians who have obtained authority from the Animal
Control Board to issue them or from a duly authorized employee at the Animal
Shelter upon presentation of a certificate of current vaccination.
   (e)   Veterinarian Registering. Upon application by a veterinarian, the
Board shall furnish such veterinarian with a supply of prenumbered vaccination
registration certificates and corresponding tags. The veterinarian shall be
authorized to receive applications and issue certificates and tags for animals
at the time of vaccination. Copies of all certificates issued shall be
transmitted to the Board in accordance with arrangements made by the Board with
the veterinarian. When applying for additional certificates and tags, the
veterinarian shall account to the Board for all those previously supplied to
him. At that time the veterinarian shall remit to the Animal Shelter all fees
collected. The veterinarian shall be held financially responsible for any other
certificates and tags no longer in his possession that have not been issued or
voided and returned to the Animal Shelter. All fees collected by veterinarians
are payable to the Board upon demand.
   (f)   Fee. Application for initial issuance or renewal of each registration
must be made by the owner in writing or in person and must be accompanied by a
fee of one dollar ($1.00).
   (g)   Renewal. A registration shall be renewed not later than the date of
expiration of the current vaccination period for which it was issued, as
defined in subsection (a) hereof.
   (h)   Use of Registration. No person shall use a certificate or tag for any
animal other than the one for which it was issued.
   (i)   Transfer of Registration. If there is a change in ownership of a
registered dog, the new owner shall have the registration transferred to his
name. Application for such transfer shall be made at the Animal Shelter in
writing or in person and must be accompanied by a fee of twenty-five cents
($0.25).
   (j)   Registration Fee Exemption. Any person owning and using a dog for
leading because of a visual handicap is exempt from the vaccination-
registration fee.
   (k)   Responsibility. Eligibility for the registration fee exemption does
not release the owner of responsibility under other provisions of this section.
   (l)   Loss of Tag. If the tag is lost or destroyed the owner shall apply at
the Animal Shelter in writing or in person for a new tag by presentation of the
applicable vaccination-registration certificate accompanied by a fee of fifty
cents ($0.50).
(Ord. 38-66. Passed 11-9-66.)
604.11  SEEING-EYE DOGS.
   Any dog trained to guide any blind person shall be admitted, when actually
accompanying such blind person, to any public place or vehicle which such blind
person may have the lawful right to enter, if the dog is currently vaccinated
and registered.
(Ord. 38-66. Passed 11-9-66.)
604.12  DOG BITING.
   (a)   Reporting Animal Bites. It shall be the duty of every physician or
other medical practitioner, the owner of the dog involved and/or the victim to
report to the Board the names and addresses of persons treated for bites
inflicted by dogs, together with such other information as is pertinent to
rabies control. It shall be the duty of any person having knowledge of a dog
bite incident to notify the Board of such incident and to provide such
information, upon request of the Animal Warden or any officer, as is pertinent
to rabies control.
   (b)   Confinement. Any dog that bites a person shall be confined by the
owner in and at a place designated by the Animal Warden or his duly authorized
representative in such a way as to prevent such dog from coming into contact
with another animal or person and/ or from escaping. Such confinement shall be
at the owner's expense. Such dog shall be confined ten days from the date of
the dog bite incident and/or until such time as a veterinarian has authorized,
in writing, its release or nonconfinement.
   (c)   Rabies Test. It shall be the duty of the owner and/or veterinarian to
forward the head of any dog that dies within ten days of biting any person to
the Pennsylvania Department of Health. The cost of sending such head shall be
borne by the owner.
(Ord. 38-66. Passed 11-9-66.)
604.13  FEES AND CHARGES.
   The Board is hereby empowered to establish the following penalties and fees:
   (a)   Impoundment penalty for a licensed or unlicensed dog shall be five
dollars ($5.00).
   (b)   A daily board fee of one dollar ($1.00) shall be charged for every day
or fraction thereof that an animal is confined to the Animal Shelter.
   (c)   A fee of three dollars ($3.00) may be charged to the owner for
distemper shots administered to dogs impounded at the Animal Shelter.
   (d)   A fee of three dollars ($3.00) may be charged for animal pickup
service requested by the owner of the animal.
   (e)   A fee of three dollars ($3.00) may be charged for euthanasia service
requested by the owner of the animal.
   (f)   Any dog to be redeemed by or released to an owner shall be required to
meet the vaccination and/or licensing requirements of this chapter prior to
such redemption and release. If vaccination and/or licensing is performed at
the Animal Shelter, the current fees for such services shall be paid prior to
such release.
(Ord. 38-66. Passed 11-9-66.)
604.14  DOG AND CAT NUISANCES.
   (a)   Any dog or cat which, by frequent or habitual barking, howling,
screeching, yelping or baying, or in any other way or manner, injures or
disturbs the quiet of any person or the community, or which disturbs or
endangers the comfort, repose or health of persons, is hereby declared to be
committing a nuisance.
   (b)   Any dog or cat which is molesting passersby, chasing vehicles and/or
attacking other domestic animals is hereby declared to be a nuisance.
   (c)   Any dog or cat which scratches, digs or defecates upon any lawn, tree,
shrub, plant, building or any other public or private property, other than the
property of the owner or person in charge or control of such animal, is hereby
declared to be a nuisance.
   (d)   Where the owner or person in charge or control of such dog or cat
immediately removes all feces deposited on private or public property and
disposes of the same in a sanitary manner, such nuisance shall be considered
abated.
   (e)   No owner or person having custody of such a dog or cat shall permit it
to commit such nuisances.
(Ord. 12-77. Passed 5-11-77.)
   (f)   [EDITOR’S NOTE: This subsection was repealed by Ord. 07-15, passed 10-
15-15.]
   (g)   Any dog or cat which attacks and/or bites one or more persons two or
more times may be declared a nuisance by the District Justice, and the District
Justice may order that such dog or cat shall not be kept in the Shenango Valley
or shall be destroyed, or such District Justice may eliminate the dog or cat as
a nuisance by some other procedure. The District Justice has the right and
authority to determine the disposition of a dog or cat which attacks and/or
bites one or more persons one or more times, based on the severity of the
attack and/or bite and the resulting physical human suffering.
(Ord. 24-78. Passed 8-28-78.)
604.15  HUMANE CARE OF DOGS AND CATS.
   (a)   No person shall keep or harbor any dog or cat in the Shenango Valley
as so to create offensive odors or unsanitary conditions which are a menace to
the health, comfort or safety of the public and that of the dog or cat.
   (b)   Every dog or cat that is kept outdoors must be provided with adequate
shelter or a dog house. The dog house must be large enough for the dog to
assume all normal positions and must also be draft-free with a good floor and a
sound roof. It should contain straw, hay or shavings.
   (c)   No dog or cat shall be kept in a filthy, unsanitary condition. It
shall not have to walk, eat or sleep in its own urine or fecal matter.
   (d)   Every dog or cat shall be given food placed in containers and not just
thrown on the ground. Fresh water shall also be provided.
   (e)   Any person found not providing humane care for his dog or cat will be
considered in violation of this section.
   (f)   No person shall poison or ill-treat a dog or cat, or deny a dog or cat
veterinary care when needed to prevent suffering, or abandon a dog or cat in
the Shenango Valley.
(Ord. 12-77.  Passed 5-11-77.)
604.16  STRAY CATS.
   The Animal Warden or his duly authorized representative is hereby authorized
to receive any cat which is deemed to be without ownership and/or any cat
surrendered to the Animal Warden by its owner to be destroyed in some humane
manner or to be put up for adoption.
(Ord. 38-66. Passed 11-9-66.)
604.17  NOTICE OF VIOLATION.
   The Animal Warden or any other employee duly authorized by the Board or any
Shenango Valley municipal policeman shall have the authority to issue to any
owner of a licensed dog found at large, without seizing and/or detaining such
dog, a Notice of Violation in lieu of impoundment. A Notice of Violation shall
be a printed form similar in design to a traffic and/or parking ticket in use
by police departments and in sufficient duplicates so as to afford a copy for
the violator, the Board and for any other authorized records.
(Ord. 38-66. Passed 11-9-66.)
604.18  ENFORCEMENT.
   For the purpose of discharging the duties imposed by this chapter and by the
Dog Law of 1965, and for enforcing the provisions of the same, the Code and
Health officers of the City, in addition to all officers duly authorized by the
Board and all Shenango Valley municipal policemen are hereby empowered to enter
upon any private property for the purpose of enforcing this chapter, to
ascertain whether any dog is present, kept, harbored or cared for thereon, to
ascertain whether the owner has secured a current calendar year Pennsylvania
dog license and tag, to issue notices of violation to owners of dogs found
running at large, and/or to impound dogs found to be in violation of this
chapter. Such officers are hereby granted all powers, duties and
responsibilities authorized in the Dog Law of 1965 to be delegated to such
officers by the Secretary of the Pennsylvania Department of Agriculture. No
person shall interfere, hinder or molest any officer in the performance of his
duties.
(Ord. 38-66. Passed 11-9-66; Ord. 05-04.  Passed 9-16-04.)
604.99  PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
202.99 for general Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)
   Whoever permits a licensed dog to be at large, in violation of Section
604.06, and receives a Notice of Violation for permitting his dog to be at
large, may discharge the penalty incurred by depositing at the Animal Shelter
the Notice of Violation, together with the sum of five dollars ($5.00), within
ten days of such violation.
(Ord. 38-66. Passed 11-9-66.)
CHAPTER 612
Drugs
612.01   Drug paraphernalia defined.
612.03   Evidence.
612.02   Use, sale and advertisement of drug paraphernalia prohibited.
 
612.99   Penalty.
612.01  DRUG PARAPHERNALIA DEFINED.
   As used in this chapter "drug paraphernalia" means all equipment, products
and materials of any kind which are used, intended for use, or designed for
use, in planting, propagating, cultivating, growing, harvesting, manufacturing,
compounding, converting, producing, processing, preparing, testing, analyzing,
packaging, repackaging, storing, containing, concealing or injecting,
ingesting, inhaling or otherwise introducing into the human body, a controlled
substance in violation of this chapter. The term includes, but is not limited
to:
   (a)   Kits used, intended for use, or designed for use, in planting,
propagating, cultivating, growing or harvesting of any species of plant which
is a controlled substance or from which a controlled substance can be derived;
   (b)   Kits used, intended for use, or designed for use, in manufacturing,
compounding, converting, producing, processing or preparing controlled
substances;
   (c)   Isomerization devices used, intended for use, or designed for use, in
increasing the potency of any species of plant which is a controlled substance;
   (d)   Testing equipment used, intended for use, or designed for use, in
identifying or in analyzing the strength, effectiveness or purity of controlled
substances;
   (e)   Scales and balances used, intended for use, or designed for use, in
weighing or measuring controlled substances;
   (f)   Dilutants and adulterants, such as quinine hydrochloride, mannitol,
mannite, dextrose and lactose, used, intended for use, or designed for use, in
cutting controlled substances;
   (g)   Separation gins and sifters used, intended for use, or designed for
use, in removing twigs and seeds from, or in otherwise cleaning or refining,
marijuana;
   (h)   Blenders, bowls, containers, spoons and mixing devices used, intended
for use, or designed for use, in compounding controlled substances;
   (i)   Capsules, balloons, envelopes and other containers used, intended for
use, or designed for use, in packaging small quantities of controlled
substances;
   (j)   Containers and other objects used, intended for use, or designed for
use, in storing or concealing controlled substances;
   (k)   Hypodermic syringes, needles and other objects used, intended for use,
or designed for use, in parenterally injecting controlled substances into the
human body;
   (l)   Objects used, intended for use, or designed for use, in ingesting,
inhaling or otherwise introducing marijuana, cocaine, hashish or hashish oil
into the human body, such as:
      (1)   Metal, wooden, acrylic, glass, stone, plastic or ceramic pipes,
with or without screens, permanent screens, hashish heads or punctured metal
bowls;
      (2)   Water pipes;
      (3)   Carburetion tubes and devices;
      (4)   Smoking and carburetion masks;
      (5)   Roach clips, meaning objects used to hold burning material, such as
a marijuana cigarette, that has become too small or too short to be held in the
hand;
      (6)   Miniature cocaine spoons and cocaine vials;
      (7)   Chamber pipes;
      (8)   Carburetor pipes;
      (9)   Electric pipes;
      (10)   Air-driven pipes;
      (11)   Chillums;
      (12)   Bongs; and
      (13)   Ice pipes or chillers.
(Ord. 22-80. Passed 10-22-80.)
612.02  USE, SALE AND ADVERTISEMENT OF DRUG PARAPHERNALIA PROHIBITED.
   (a)   No person shall use, or possess with intent to use, drug paraphernalia
to plant, propagate, cultivate, grow, harvest, manufacture, compound, convert,
produce, process, prepare, test, analyze, pack, repack, store, contain, conceal
or inject, ingest, inhale or otherwise introduce into the human body, a
controlled substance.
   (b)   No person shall deliver, sell, possess with intent to deliver or sell,
or manufacture with intent to deliver or sell, drug paraphernalia, knowing that
it will be used to plant, propagate, cultivate, grow, harvest, manufacture,
compound, convert, produce, process, prepare, test, analyze, pack, repack,
store, contain, conceal or inject, ingest, inhale or otherwise introduce into
the human body, a controlled substance.
   (c)   No person shall place in any newspaper, magazine, handbill or other
publication any advertisement, knowing that the purpose of the advertisement,
in whole or in part, is to promote the sale of objects designed or intended for
use as drug paraphernalia.
(Ord. 22-80. Passed 10-22-80.)
612.03  EVIDENCE.
   In determining whether an object is "drug paraphernalia," a court or other
authority should consider, in addition to all other logically relevant factors,
the following:
   (a)   Statements by an owner or by anyone in control of the object
concerning its use;
   (b)   Prior convictions, if any, of an owner or of anyone in control of the
object, under any city, state or Federal law relating to any controlled
substance;
   (c)   The proximity of the object, in time and space, to a direct violation
of a provision of this chapter;
   (d)   The proximity of the object to a controlled substance;
   (e)   The existence of any residue of controlled substances on the object;
   (f)   Direct or circumstantial evidence of the intent of an owner, or of
anyone in control of the object, to deliver it to persons whom he knows, or
should reasonably know, intend to use the object to facilitate a violation of a
provision of this chapter; the innocence of the owner or of anyone in control
of the object, as to a direct violation of a provision of this chapter, shall
not prevent a finding that the object is intended for use, or designed for use,
as "drug paraphernalia;"
   (g)   Instructions, oral or written, provided with the object concerning its
use;
   (h)   Descriptive materials accompanying the object which explain or depict
its use;
   (i)   National and local advertising concerning its use;
   (j)   The manner in which the object is displayed for sale;
   (k)   Direct or circumstantial evidence of the ratio of sales of the object
to the total sales of the business enterprise;
   (l)   The existence and scope of legitimate uses for the object in the
community; and (m) Expert testimony concerning its use.
(Ord. 22-80. Passed 10-22-80.)
612.99  PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
202.99 for general Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)
