1041.04  EXTRAORDINARY WASTE; PERMITS AND EXEMPTIONS.
   (a)   Owners of property classified industrial, as detailed in this chapter,
and/or property producing extraordinary waste, shall be required to obtain a
permit to discharge into the City sewerage system, unless exempted by the City.
The permit and/or exemption shall be issued by the City and shall be predicated
upon an evaluation of the premises by the City Engineer, together with
information submitted by the applicant. Application forms, permit forms and
exemption forms shall be as established by the City and shall include, but not
necessarily be limited to, the following information:
      (1)   The name and address of the applicant;
      (2)   The address of the facility generating extraordinary waste;
      (3)   The point of the proposed discharge;
      (4)   The volume of essential characteristics of the proposed discharge;
      (5)   Plans and specifications for building sewers, together with
proposed facilities for control, monitoring and gauging, if required; and
      (6)   Any other essential data that may be determined by the City
Engineer to be necessary in the determination of the acceptability and
suitability of permitting such waste to be discharged into the public system.
   (b)   No person shall discharge, cause to be discharged or attempt to
discharge any extraordinary waste to any public sewer in the City until he or
she has obtained a proper permit therefor as outlined in this section.
(Ord. 20-86. Passed 12-29-86.)
1041.05  INDUSTRIAL CLASSIFICATION.
   Users shall be classified as industrial according to the current issue of
the Standard Industrial Classification Manual employed by the U.S. Bureau of
Census in the periodic "Census of Manufacturers," a copy of which shall be
available to the public for examination in the office of the City Clerk during
normal office hours.
(Ord. 20-86. Passed 12-29-86.)
1041.06  SEWAGE STRENGTH DETERMINATION FOR SURCHARGE.
   The strength of sewage discharged into the public sewer shall be determined
in one of the following ways at the option of the City:
   (a)   Sampling of Average Characteristics. Samples of the sewage discharge
shall be taken at a sampling point provided by the property owner and
acceptable to the City in accordance with this chapter and other regulations
and rules promulgated by the City. Sufficient samplings shall be made to enable
the determination of a reasonable average value for the quality and
characteristics of the sewage discharge satisfactory to the City. Samplings and
laboratory evaluation shall be made by the City in accordance with the current
edition of "Standard Methods for Examination of Water and Waste Water," as
published by the American Public Health Association, or regulations of the
Pennsylvania Department of Environmental Resources. The average characteristics
thus determined shall be used as the basis for extraordinary waste surcharge
calculations. The City shall review such average characteristics as often as it
deems necessary to maintain an average characteristic with reasonable accuracy.
   (b)   Sampling of Individual Characteristics. When, in the opinion of the
City Engineer, a reasonable average sewage characteristic cannot be obtained as
outlined in subsection (a) hereof, the installation of a device capable of
automatic sampling may be required. Such device shall be of a type acceptable
to the City, shall be installed in accordance with plans and specifications
having prior City approval, shall be installed in a control manhole as required
by ordinances of the City, and shall be installed, maintained and repaired by
the owner at his or her expense. Sampling by means of this instrument shall be
at a time and in a manner directed by the City Engineer in order to secure a
reasonable and representative sample satisfactory to the City. The results of
this sampling shall be used in the computation of surcharges.
(Ord. 20-86. Passed 12-29-86.)
1041.07  PRIVATE WATER SUPPLIES; METERS.
   (a)   Meters Required. If any person discharges into the City sewerage
system and obtains part or all of the water used by him or her from a source
other than the Shenango Valley Water Company, then such water supply or source
shall be metered in a manner acceptable to the City. If the water from such
water supply is not measured by a water meter or is measured by a water meter
not acceptable to the City, then the City shall install a suitable meter or
have such a meter installed so as to properly measure all water consumption on
the premises. The meter size shall be determined by the City according to
standard engineering procedures for sizing water meters.
   (b)   Installation Costs. All costs for water meter installation, including
the cost of the meter, shall be paid by the City. The property owner shall be
required to provide access for meter placement and for subsequent readings. The
property owner shall also be required to pay a deposit for the meter in
accordance with the meter size as shown in subsection (d) hereof. The deposit
shall be refunded in full by the City upon presentation of the receipt for the
deposit payment, together with return of the meter to the City in acceptable
working condition. The City may withhold from any meter deposit any sums
necessary to cover unpaid sewer rentals or charges, as of the date of removal
of the meter, or to pay for any damage done to the meter while in the
possession of the property owner.
   (c)   Notice of Intention to Remove Meter. Any property owner having a City
installed meter on his or her premises, who sells or vacates the premises, or
for any other reason desires to have the meter removed and a refund of his or
her deposit made to him or her, shall give the City written notice of his or
her intention to sell or vacate the premises or to install or have installed a
meter supplied by the Shenango Valley Water Company if such company makes water
available to the premises. This notice shall be given to the City at least
twenty-four hours in advance of the time for removal of the meter in order that
the City may have a final reading made, establish a final billing for the
premises and make arrangements to have the meter removed.
   (d)   Deposits.   Meter deposits required in accordance with this section
shall be as follows:
 
Standard Meter Size  Deposit Compound Meter Size (in.) Deposit
(in.)

(Ord. 20-86. Passed 12-29-86.)
1041.08  RENTALS FOR VACANT PREMISES; DISCONNECTIONS AND RECONNECTIONS.
   The procedure described herein shall apply to all premises utilizing the
City sewerage system, either directly or indirectly, to all premises connected
thereto and to all premises paying sewer rental to the City either on a flat-
rate basis or a water-consumption basis. When any such premises becomes vacant,
the sewer rental shall continue so long as the building sewer or sewer lateral
is connected to, the City public sewer. Owners of premises paying on a flat-
rate basis shall continue to pay at the applicable flat rate. Owners of
premises paying sewer rental on a water-consumption basis shall continue to pay
the base quarterly charge, plus a flow charge if water is used. If no water is
used, the sewer rental shall be continued predicated upon one EDU per quarter.
If the water meter is removed, the sewer rental shall be continued predicated
upon an amount equal to the average of the last three months of actual usage.
If the premises are disconnected from the sewer by proper disconnection of the
sewer lateral, the rental charge shall be discontinued at the beginning of the
next billing period. If at a later date it is desired to reconnect such
premises to the public sewer, standard connection procedures as detailed in
this chapter for new sewer connections shall be followed, including the
obtaining of A permit and the payment of a connection fee. The connection fee
charged for reconnection shall be based on the new type of occupancy intended.
Any lateral to be reconnected shall be subject to inspection and/or test before
reconnection as may be required by the City at its discretion to determine the
acceptability of the existing lateral in compliance with this chapter and other
ordinances of the City.
(Ord. 20-86. Passed 12-29-86.)
1041.09  REDUCTION IN SEWER CHARGES FOR WATER EXCLUDED FROM SEWERS
   (a)   Any user of the City sewerage system paying sewer rentals or charges
on the basis of metered water, who discharges less than his or her total water
usage into the sewerage system, may make written application to the City for a
reduction in his or her sewer rental because of water excluded from the City
sewerage system. Such application shall be in a form acceptable to the City and
shall contain information as the City may reasonably require, including
supporting data fully describing other sources of water, as well as the manner
of disposition of water alleged to be excluded from the City sewerage system.
If it is established to the satisfaction of the City Engineer that a portion of
the water utilized by the premises does not and cannot enter the City sewerage
system, then the City may require or permit the installation of additional
meters at the owner's or interested party's expense, in such a manner as to
measure either the quantity of water actually excluded from the City sewerage
system or the actual quantity of water discharged thereto.. Meters shall be of
a type suitable for the service they are to perform and shall meet with the
approval of the City Engineer. In addition, they shall be installed and
maintained in a manner satisfactory to the City. The City Engineer may
establish reasonable regulations to ensure the integrity of the measuring
devices to be accessible to him or her at any reasonable hour for inspection.
(Ord. 20-86. Passed 12-29-86.)
   (b)   Any residential user of the City sewerage system paying sewer rentals
or charges on the basis of metered water may have excluded therefrom, upon
proper application to the City, that amount of water used for purposes of
filling a residential swimming pool, provided that:
      (1)   Water discharged from the residential swimming pool is not, in any
manner, discharged into the City's sanitary sewerage system; and
      (2)   Prior to use of water for purposes of filling a pool, the user
advises the City of his or her intended use of water for the purposes stated
and, further, makes appropriate arrangements with representatives of the City
to monitor and verify the amount of water actually used for the purposes
intended. Upon verification by the City, the proper ,City officials are hereby
authorized to make appropriate refunds or credits with respect to the amount of
metered water consumed for purposes of filling and/or maintaining residential
swimming pools.
(Ord. 8-88. Passed 7-27-88.)
1041.10  COMPUTATION OF REDUCTION OF SEWER RENTALS.
   Persons complying with this chapter may be granted a reduction in their
sewer bilis. The amount of reduction shall be based on the volume of water
excluded from the City sewerage system. The rental rates shall then be based on
the net amount of the discharge to the City sewerage system, plus any
surcharges or other rental modifications, but in no event shall any user pay
less than the minimum rate for his or her classification as set forth in this
chapter.
(Ord. 20-86. Passed 12-29-86.)
1041.11  METER REPAIR.
   If the City has any reason to believe that any meter or metering device
installed pursuant to Section
1041.09 is inaccurate or in need of repair, then the owner, at his or her own
expense, shall have it tested and/or repaired and restored to accuracy to the
satisfaction of the City. Such testing or restoration to accuracy shall be
completed within sixty days of notice from the City Engineer. A reasonable
interim sewer rental rate may be established by the City for that period during
which suitable metering is not provided by the owner, or the owner may be
required to establish suitable interim metering subject to City approval.
(Ord. 20-86. Passed 12-29-86.)
1041.12  ALTERNATIVE METHODS OF MEASUREMENT OF DIVERTED WATER.
   If the City finds that it is not practical to measure either the actual
sewage or the flow of diverted water, it may, at its discretion, approve some
other manner of computing or estimating the amount of water diverted from the
City sewerage system.
(Ord. 20-86. Passed 12-29-86.)
1041.13  BILLING; DEFAULT OF PAYMENT.
   (a)   (1)   Bills for sewer rentals and charges imposed by this chapter
shall be rendered periodically, being not less often than quarterly nor more
often than monthly, for the period immediately preceding the date of the bill. 
Said bill shall be due and payable in full as of the date rendered.  If not
paid within thirty days of rendering, said bill shall have added thereto a
penalty in the amount of five percent of its face.  If said bill and penalty
are not paid in full within sixty days of the original rendering, then there
shall be added to the amount then owing interest at the rate of one and one-
half percent per month for each month or portion thereof until paid in full.
      (2)   If any person refuses or neglects to pay said sewer rentals and
charges for a period in excess of sixty days after rendering, the City may lien
and/or collect the same in any manner authorized by law and/or may discontinue
sewer service to any premises owned or occupied by said delinquent.  In
addition thereto, the City shall add to any balance owing all costs and fees,
including reasonable attorneys' fees, incurred by the City in its collection
effort.
(Ord. 8-00. Passed 5-25-00.)
   (b)   If the owner or occupant of the premises serviced by the Shenango
Valley Water Company neglects or fails to pay any bill rendered to him or her
for sewer rental or charge for use of the City sewerage system, the Shenango
Valley Water Company is hereby directed, upon request of the City, to shut off
the supply of water to such premises until such overdue rentals, rates and
charges, together with any penalties and interest thereon and the costs of
cutting off and restoring such service, have been paid, provided that:
      (1)   At least ten days written notice of an intention to do so has been
mailed to the person liable for the payment of the rentals or charges;
      (2)   Written notice has been posted at the main entrance of the premises
affected; and
      (3)   (EDITOR'S NOTE: Division (b)(3) was repealed by Ordinance 15-02,
passed September 26, 2002.)
(Ord. 15-90. Passed 12-19-90; Ord. 15-02. Passed 9-26-02.)
   (c)   The City may periodically provide for the publication of the names of
persons delinquent in the payment of bills for sewer rentals and charges
imposed by this chapter.  Not less than thirty days prior to said proposed
publication, the City shall cause to have mailed to each record owner, by
regular mail, postage prepaid, a notice of the City's intent to publicize said
notice, setting forth the following:
      (1)   The specific address of the premises for which the sewer rentals
and charges imposed by this chapter are delinquent and the name of each record
owner;
      (2)   The outstanding principal sum delinquent as of the date of the
notice;
      (3)   All accrued interest, penalties and charges through the date of the
notice;
      (4)   The date or dates of proposed publication, along with the manner of
proposed publication (newspaper, radio, cable, television, billboard, etc.);
      (5)   The deadline for curing the delinquency in order to prevent the
proposed publication; and
      (6)   The amount required to be paid to cure the delinquency and prevent
the proposed publication.
(Ord. 4-97. Passed 7-24-97.)
1041.14  RESPONSIBILITY FOR RENTALS.
   The owner of property connected to the City sewerage system is responsible
for all sewer rentals or charges for sewer services rendered to any tenant or
occupant of such property.
(Ord. 20-86. Passed 12-29-86.)
1041.15  COMPUTATION OF RENTAL DURING PORTION OF QUARTER.
   Whenever sewer service begins after the first day or terminates before the
last day of any calendar quarter, the sewer rental for such period shall be a
pro rata amount for that portion of the period during which the property is
served. However, in making any such apportionment, a fraction of the calendar
month amounting to one-half or more of a calendar month shall be counted as a
full month, and a fraction of a calendar month amounting to less than one-half
of a calendar month shall be disregarded.
(Ord. 20-86. Passed 12-29-86.)

1044.01  INSTALLATION OF MAINS AND LINES.

street of the City, any water main or service line at a depth less than forty-
two inches from the surface of the street, as shown by the grade established by
the City Engineer, nor shall any water main be of a size less than four inches
in diameter, and of pipe other than cast iron, except in such instances as may
be specially permitted by Council.
(Ord. 98. Passed 6-28-21.)

CHAPTER 1060
Residential Garbage and Rubbish Collection and Disposal
   EDITOR'S NOTE: Resolution 22-74, passed April 24, 1974, adopted the Mercer
County Solid Waste Management Plan, which was submitted pursuant to Act 241.
Resolution 22-74 was amended by Resolution 215-91, passed October 23, 1991.
Resolution 43-85, passed March 21, 1985, approved the Resource Recovery
Feasibility Study of Mercer County as the official updating of the Mercer
County Solid Waste Management Plan and approved the Plan as the City's Plan for
Collection and Disposal of Municipal Waste under the provisions of Act 97, The
Pennsylvania Solid Waste Management Act.
   Resolution 48-97, passed April 29, 1997, ratified the Mercer County Solid
Waste Management Plan, upon recommendation of the Mercer County Solid Waste
Authority.
   Copies of these Resolutions may be obtained, at cost, from the Clerk of
Council.
1060.01   Definitions.
1060.02   Administration.
1060.03   Precollection practices.
1060.04   Collection practices.
1060.05   Notice of recycling program.
1060.06   Containers.
1060.07   Reports of change of occupancy.
1060.08   Separate offenses.
1060.09   Authority. (Repealed)
1060.10   Separate offenses. (Repealed)
 
1060.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Garbage disposal - see GEN. OFF.
664.11
   Licensed haulers and disposers of garbage and rubbish - see S.U. & P.S. Ch.
1064
   Housing Code requirements - see B. & H.
1488.05(f), (g),
1488.12(b), (c)
1060.01     DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter, except in those instances where the context clearly
indicates otherwise:
   (a)   "Garbage" means all refuse and animal and vegetable matter which has
been used for food for humans, and all animals and vegetable matter which was
intended to be so used, and includes condemned foods. This meaning includes
excess fruit from trees.
   (b)   "Rubbish" means all rags, crockery, bottles, tin cans, paper and other
household refuse. However, the term "rubbish" does not include refuse caused by
repairs, alterations and new construction or demolition of buildings and
sidewalks, nor does it include water tanks, sinks, stoves or similar discarded
appliances, or yard waste, plant growth or recyclables.
   (c)   "Refuse" means garbage, rubbish, recyclables and yard waste.
   (d)   "Person" means a natural person, firm, co-partnership, association or
corporation.
   (e)   "Trash" means furniture, springs and mattresses, furnace pipe, stoves,
water boilers, tires, metal cooking utensils, toys, porcelain, carpeting,
household appliances, iron, steel, bulky items and the residue of alterations,
demolition or new construction of buildings and sidewalks.
   (f)   "Family unit" means every individual or group of individuals occupying
or using a dwelling of whatever kind or nature, or a part of the same, whether
they are the legal owners or not.
   (g)   "Recyclables" means all aluminum, bi-metal products, glass, newsprint
and plastics.
   (h)   "Yard waste" means grass clippings, leaves and brush from trees and
bushes.
(Ord. 9-90. Passed 9-26-90.)
1060.02  ADMINISTRATION.
   (a)   All residential garbage, rubbish, recyclables and yard waste
accumulated in the City shall be collected, conveyed and disposed of by the
City, or by contract let by the City.
   (b)   No person shall collect, accumulate or convey over any of the streets
or alleys of the City or dispose of any residential garbage, rubbish,
recyclables or yard waste accumulated in the City without first securing a
permit or license therefor from the proper licensing agent of the City.
   (c)   All collection and disposal of residential garbage, rubbish,
recyclables and yard waste in the City shall be under the supervision of the
Director of Public Works. He shall make regulations concerning the days of
collection, the type and location of waste containers and such other matters
pertaining to the collection and disposal of refuse as he sees fit. Such
regulations shall be subject to the approval of Council and shall not be
inconsistent with the provisions of this chapter.
   (d)   It is the intent of this chapter that commercial and industrial
establishments shall be bound by all provisions of this chapter, excepting only
the disposal of garbage, rubbish, recyclables and yard waste which shall be
provided for by persons licensed by the City and not by the City itself, as is
the case with residential waste.
   (e)   All persons, firms, co-partnerships, associations, or corporations,
that own property in the City of Sharon, that is used for residential purposes,
shall be responsible to a service arrangement with the Contractor designated by
the City to remove residential garbage. For purposes of this subsection, the
Grantor on any unrecorded Article of Agreement or Agreement of sale shall be
considered the owner of the property which is the subject of same.
(Ord. 9-90. Passed 9-26-90; Ord. 18-03.  Passed 11-24-03; Ord. 08-16.  Passed
11- -16.)
1060.03  PRECOLLECTION PRACTICES.
   (a)   Preparation of Refuse. All rubbish and garbage, before being placed
into receptacles for collection, shall have been drained free of all liquid.
Garbage shall be wrapped in paper or otherwise contained. All recyclable
materials shall be separated from garbage into one reusable container. All yard
waste shall be separated from garbage, rubbish and recyclables and shall be
placed for collection in the manner hereinafter provided.
   (b)   Refuse Containers.
      (1)   All containers for the storage of garbage, rubbish and recyclables
shall be verminproof, waterproof, made of noncorrodible metal or similar
material equipped with handles and tightly fitting lids at all times.
   Also, specially constructed or plastic bags may be used provided they are
securely tied and placed in an orderly manner, and appropriately marked in the
case of recyclables.
      (2)   All containers must be maintained in a sanitary condition and the
collector is under no obligation to empty unsanitary containers.
      (3)   Refuse not confined within suitable containers will not be
collected. No container, including contents, shall weigh over fifty pounds.
      (4)   Defective containers must be replaced within two weeks of notice by
the collector. If such container is not replaced, then the collector may refuse
service until such time as the container is replaced.
   (c)   Storage and Accumulation of Refuse.
      (1)   No person shall place any refuse in any street, alley or public
place, or upon any private property whether owned by such person or not, within
the City, except for compost or in proper receptacles for collection and at
proper points of collection as hereinafter set forth in this chapter. No person
shall throw or deposit any refuse in any stream or other body of water or in
any place in violation of this chapter or any other law of the Commonwealth.
      (2)   Any unauthorized accumulation of refuse on any premises is hereby
declared to be a nuisance and is prohibited. Failure to remove any existing
accumulation of refuse after twenty-four hours notice by the City shall be
deemed a violation of this chapter.
      (3)   No person, other than the occupants of the premises on which refuse
receptacles are stored, or the collector, shall remove the covers or any of the
contents of refuse receptacles, or remove, displace or tamper with any item set
out for collection.
      (4)   No person shall place any refuse items for pick-up in, on or
adjacent to the right of way of any public street, upon any public sidewalk or
upon property abutting any public sidewalk or public street prior to 12:00 noon
on the day immediately preceding the scheduled pick-up. No person shall be
charged before a magistrate with a violation of this paragraph unless such
person has written notice, on at least one occasion, of the City's intent to
prosecute for such violation.
   (d)   Special Refuse Problems.
      (1)   Contagious disease refuse. The removal of wearing apparel, bedding
or other refuse from homes or other places where highly infectious or
contagious diseases have prevailed shall be performed only under the
supervision and direction of the Health Officer. Such refuse shall not be
placed in containers for regular collection.
      (2)   Inflammable or explosive refuse. Highly inflammable or explosive
materials shall not be placed in containers for regular collection but shall be
disposed of as directed by the Director of Public Works at the expense of the
owner or possessor thereof.
      (3)   Prohibited refuse. No person shall place, for collection,
batteries, paint or oil. Said items shall be disposed of only upon special
direction from the Department of Public Works and shall not be part of the
regular and ordinary refuse pick-up within the City. In addition, no person
shall place for collection more than one tire per month for refuse collection.
      (4)   Points of collection. Refuse receptacles shall be placed for
collection at ground level on the property near by but not within the cartway
of a street or alley, and readily accessible to the side of the street or alley
from which collection is made.
(Ord. 9-90. Passed 9-26-90. )
1060.04  COLLECTION PRACTICES.
   (a)   Frequency of Collection. Refuse shall be collected at least once each
week by the City.
   (b)   Limitation on Quantity. It is the intent of this chapter that the
reasonable accumulation of refuse of each family unit for the collection period
will be collected for the standard charge. The Director of Public Works may
refuse to collect unreasonable amounts of refuse or may make an additional
charge for such amounts. No person, other than a resident of the City, shall
place for disposal any refuse on streets or alleys. In addition, no resident of
the City shall accept, from any person not a resident, refuse which is
intended, or which the resident should reasonably believe to be intended, for
disposal by the City as part of the City's residential refuse collection.
   (c)   Special Refuse Problems. Items not part of the City's regular garbage,
rubbish, recyclable or yard waste collection program shall be collected and
disposed of only through prior satisfactory arrangements having been made with
the Director.
(Ord. 9-90. Passed 9-26-90.)
1060.05  NOTICE OF RECYCLING PROGRAM.
   The City will, at least thirty days prior to the commencement of its
recycling program, give written notice to each property owner of the provisions
of the City's recycling program. In addition, the City will, at biannual
intervals, give public notice of the provisions of this chapter as they affect
recycling.
(Ord. 9-90. Passed 9-26-90.)
1060.06  CONTAINERS.
   It is the intent of the City to supply to each residential unit a container
which is to be designated for recyclables. Each resident will be required to
execute a receipt acknowledging custody of the container and his or her
obligation to maintain the same at his or her residence for use by himself or
herself or his or her grantees, successors and assigns. Containers shall, at
all times, remain the property of the City.
(Ord. 9-90. Passed 9-26-90.)
1060.07  REPORTS OF CHANGE OF OCCUPANCY.
   After final passage of this chapter, it shall be the duty of the owner or
agent of property in the City, occupied either as a family unit or as an
individual within the meaning of this chapter, to report to the City any change
of occupancy of such property, and to give the name and address of such adult
occupant within thirty days after the occupancy begins. Each new occupant shall
then execute, on the form provided by the City, a receipt acknowledging
possession and custody of the recyclable containers.
(Ord. 9-90. Passed 9-26-90.)
1060.08  SEPARATE OFFENSES.
   After notice, a separate offense shall be deemed committed each day during
or on which a violation of or noncompliance with any of the provisions of this
chapter or any regulation made pursuant thereto occurs or continues, and a
single proceeding may be instituted and separate penalties imposed for each
offense.
(Ord. 9-90. Passed 9-26-90.)
1060.09  AUTHORITY. (REPEALED)
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: Section
1060.09 was repealed by implication by Ordinance 9-90, passed September 26,
1990.)
1060.10  SEPARATE OFFENSES. (REPEALED)
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: Section
1060.10 was repealed by implication by Ordinance 9-90, passed September 26,
1990. See Section
1060.08. )
1060.99  PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
202.99 for general Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)
CHAPTER 1064
Licensed Haulers and Disposers of Garbage and Rubbish
1064.01   Definitions.
1064.02   Exclusions, effective period.
1064.03   Collection area.
1064.04   Collection, transportation and disposal; license required.
1064.05   License application; fee;
1064.06   Rules and regulations.
 
1064.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Garbage disposal - see GEN. OFF.
664.11
   Residential garbage and rubbish collection and disposal - see S.U. & P. S.
Ch.
1060
1064.01  DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter, except in those instances where the context clearly
indicates otherwise:
   (a)   "Garbage" means all refuse and animal and vegetable matter which has
been used for food for man, and all refuse and animal and vegetable matter
which was intended to be so used, and includes condemned foods. This meaning
includes excess fruit from trees.
   (b)   "Rubbish" means all rags, crockery, bottles, tin cans, paper and other
household refuse. However, the term "rubbish" does not include refuse caused by
repairs, alterations and new construction or demolition of buildings and
sidewalks or water tanks, sinks, stoves or similar discarded appliances.
   (c)   "Person" means a natural person, firm, copartnership, association or
corporation.
1064.02  EXCLUSIONS.
   It is the intent of this chapter to exclude the haulers of industrial
supplies or wastes and/or any hauler subject to the rules and regulations of
the Interstate Commerce Commission or of the Pennsylvania Department of
Transportation.
1064.03  COLLECTION AREA.
   (a)   No person shall place or store any garbage, refuse or rubbish in any
street, alley or public place, or upon any private property, whether owned by
such person or not, within the City, unless it is in proper receptacles for
collection or under an express approval granted by the Director of Public
Works. No person shall throw, discharge or deposit any refuse in any stream or
other body of water.
   (b)   Any unauthorized accumulation of refuse, garbage or rubbish on any
premises situated in the City is hereby declared to be a nuisance and is
prohibited. Failure to remove any existing accumulation of refuse within thirty
days after the effective date of this chapter shall be deemed a violation of
this chapter.
   (c)   No person, other than the occupants of the premises on which refuse
receptacles are stored, or the collector, shall remove the covers or any of the
contents of refuse receptacles.
   (d)   Refuse shall be placed for collection at ground level on the property
nearby but not within the cartway of a street or alley, and readily accessible
to the side of the street or alley from which collection is made.
1064.04  COLLECTION, TRANSPORTATION AND DISPOSAL; LICENSE REQUIRED.
   (a)   No person, firm or corporation shall collect, transport or dispose of
any garbage, refuse or rubbish within the corporate limits of the City without
first obtaining a license therefor as provided in this chapter. This section
has no application to collectors employed by the City or to persons, firms or
corporations duly licensed by Municipal Authorities.
   (b)   No person, firm or corporation, in the business of hauling garbage or
rubbish, shall permit, allow or cause to be permitted or allowed, any vehicle
loaded with or containing any garbage or rubbish, to park, stand or otherwise
remain in a stationary position on a City street, alley or other public
property, or on private property, except for the express purpose of loading
garbage or rubbish, or in obedience to a police officer or traffic control
device.
(Ord. 14-82. Passed 7-28-82.)
   (c)   No person shall cause or allow, or cause to be permitted or allowed,
any vehicle to collect garbage or rubbish within the City prior to 6:00 a.m.
(Ord. 18-00. Passed 8-17-00.)
1064.05  LICENSE APPLICATION; FEE; EFFECTIVE PERIOD.
   Application for the license required by Section
1064.04 shall be made to the Code Enforcement Office and shall be accompanied
by a license fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00). After investigation by the
Code Enforcement Office, and after exhibiting compliance with all of the
regulations of such Office, the applicant shall be issued a license. Such
license shall be effective for a period of one year from the date of its
issuance.
(Ord. 44-78. Passed 12-20-78; Ord. 47-83. Passed 1-25-84.)
1064.06  RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   The Code Enforcement Office of the City or Council may promulgate rules and
regulations governing the collection, transportation or disposal of garbage and
rubbish by persons, firms or corporations, other than collectors employed by
the City, which regulations shall be filed with the City Clerk and subject to
inspection by the public. No person shall violate or fail to comply with any
such rule or regulation.
1064.99  PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
202.99 for general Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)
CHAPTER 1068
Parks and Playgrounds
1068.01   Definitions. 
1068.02   Supervision.
1068.03   Superintendent of Parks; Director of Recreation. 
1068.04   Employees.
1068.05   Enforcement. 
1068.06   Roadways.
1068.07   General regulations.
1068.08   Playgrounds.
1068.09   Group activities; assemblies.
1068.10   Permit application and issuance.
1068.11   Use of City ballfields.
1068.12   Riverview Park renamed George S. Warren Memorial Park.
 
1068.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Recreation Commission - see ADM. Ch.
262
   Dogs at large in recreational areas - see GEN. OFF.
604.06(b)
1068.01  DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter:
   (a)   "Park" means any and all parks owned or leased by the City for the
benefit of the public.
   (b)   "Playground" and "recreation area" include all playgrounds and
recreation areas owned or leased by the City for the benefit of the public.
(Ord. 14-78. Passed 5-10-78.)
1068.02  SUPERVISION.
   (a)   All parks in the City shall be operated and maintained under the
supervision of the Superintendent of Parks.
   (b)   All playgrounds in the City shall be operated under the supervision of
the Director of Recreation and maintained under the supervision of the
Superintendent of Parks.
(Ord. 14-78. Passed 5-10-78.)
1068.03  SUPERINTENDENT OF PARKS; DIRECTOR OF RECREATION.
   (a)   Superintendent of Parks. The Superintendent of Parks shall see to the
operation and maintenance of the City parks and shall perform his duties
subject to the supervision of the Director of Public Works.
(Ord. 20-78. Passed 7-26-78.)
   (b)   Director of Recreation. The Director of Recreation shall operate the
playground program and shall perform his duties subject to the supervision of
the Recreation Board.
(Ord. 14-78. Passed 5-10-78.)
1068.04  EMPLOYEES.
   (a)   The Superintendent of Parks shall have supervision over all employees
concerned with the maintenance of all parks and playgrounds and they shall
perform their duties under his supervision.
   (b)   The Director of Recreation shall have supervision over all employees
concerned with the operation of the playground program.
(Ord. 14-78. Passed 5-10-78.)
1068.05  ENFORCEMENT.
   (a)   The Superintendent of Parks shall see to the enforcement of ordinances
relating to the parks and playgrounds and he shall enforce all rules relating
to the use of parks.
   (b)   The Director of Recreation shall also see to the enforcement of
ordinances relating to the playgrounds and shall enforce all rules relating to
the use of the playgrounds.
(Ord. 14-78. Passed 5-10-78.)
1068.06  ROADWAYS.
   (a)   No truck, wagon, agricultural or construction machinery or bus for
hire shall enter upon the roads or parkways of parks or playgrounds, except in
connection with the business or activities of owners of such grounds.
   (b)   The speed and operation of all vehicles shall conform with the "due
care" required under the circumstances, and in no event shall the speed of any
vehicle exceed fifteen miles per hour.
   (c)   No vehicle, including bicycles and motorcycles, shall be parked in the
area of such grounds after 10:00 p. m. without the express consent of the City.
No vehicle shall be parked where "No Parking" signs are erected or where an
officer excludes vehicles from temporary or permanent parking privileges.
   (d)   Operators of all vehicles, including bicycles and motorcycles, shall
observe all stop signs, drive on the right side of the roadway and give the
right of way to pedestrians at all times and all places.
(Ord. 14-78. Passed 5-10-78.)
1068.07  GENERAL REGULATIONS.
   (a)   Hours of Operation. All parks and playgrounds shall be open daily to
the public from January through December of any year from 8:00 a. m. to 10:00
p. m.
   (b)   Regulations. No person shall violate any regulation governing conduct
in City parks and playgrounds, which regulation has been approved by Council.
   (c)   Clean-up. Each person or group using a public park or playground shall
clean up all debris and leave the premises in good order and the facilities in
a neat and sanitary condition.
   (d)   Prohibited Acts. No person or group using a park or playground shall
either perform or permit to be performed any of the following acts:
      (1)   Willfully mark, deface, disfigure, injure, tamper with, displace or
remove any table, bench, railing, public utility or part or appurtenance
thereof, sign, notice or placard, either temporary or permanent, monument,
stake, post or other boundary marker or other structure, including equipment,
facilities or park property, either real or personal;
      (2)   Throw, discharge or otherwise place or cause to be placed into the
waters of any fountain, pond, river or other body of water in or adjacent to a
park or playground, or into any storm sewer, or into a drain flowing into such
waters, any substance, matter or thing, liquid or solid, which will or may
result in the pollution of such waters;
      (3)   Bring in, dump, deposit or leave in a park or playground any
bottle, broken glass, ashes, paper box, can, rubbish, garbage or refuse, or
place the same into any waters in or contiguous to a park or playground, or
leave the same anywhere on the grounds thereof, other than in proper
receptacles where these are provided; where receptacles are not provided, all
such rubbish or waste shall be carried away from the park or playground by the
person responsible for its presence and properly disposed of elsewhere;
      (4)   Start any open fire for any reason, except with the special
approval of the Fire Chief for such an event; charcoal, propane or gas-type
barbecue in a suitable grill or stove shall be permitted;
      (5)   Disturb the peace or use any profane, obscene or blasphemous
language;
      (6)   Endanger the safety of any person by any conduct or act;
      (7)   Commit any assault or battery or engage in fighting;
      (8)   Bring intoxicating liquors or drugs onto the premises;
      (9)   Violate any rule for the use of the parks or playgrounds made or
approved by Council and/or the Recreation Board;
      (10)   Prevent any person from using a park or playground, or any of its
facilities, when such use is in compliance with this chapter and the rules
applicable to such use;
      (11)   Swim, bathe or wade in any waters or waterways in or adjacent to a
park or playground;
      (12)   Engage in special activities, including flying model airplanes,
golf practice and games, except at locations specifically designated for such
activities by Council; areas for such activities may be reserved by groups for
use at specified times;
      (13)   Bring any dangerous animal into a park or playground, or permit
any dog to be in a park or playground unless such dog is on a leash not more
than six feet long;
      (14)   Vend, sell, peddle or offer for sale any commodity or article
within a park or playground, unless given express written permission by
Council, except for employees or officials of a park or playground acting on
behalf of the City;
      (15)   Paste, glue, tack or otherwise post any sign, placard,
advertisement or inscription, or erect or cause to be erected any sign on any
public land or road adjacent to a park or playground, except by special
approval of Council;
      (16)   Hold a meeting or give a speech relating to religion, politics,
labor or other controversial subjects or distribute a picture, handbill,
pamphlet, periodical or other literature on religion, politics, labor or other
controversial subjects; or
      (17)   Pick, break, pull, injure or disturb any flower, tree, shrub,
fern, plant or vine on such grounds.
(Ord. 14-78. Passed 5-10-78. )
1068.08  PLAYGROUNDS.
   (a)   Equipment of the playgrounds shall be surrendered after reasonable
usage, to any other person desiring to use the same.
   (b)   Mushball, football, horseshoes or other games shall not be played
except in places provided therefor.
   (c)   Playground equipment shall be used carefully and in the manner for
which it was constructed.
(Ord. 14-78. Passed 5-10-78.)
   (d)   Effective June 1, 1994, no playground equipment presently existent in
any of the playgrounds owned and/or operated by the City or its Recreation
Board shall be used by any child over the age of fourteen years.
(Res. 107-94. Passed 6-21-94.)
   (e)   No person shall trespass, occupy or use any portion of the playgrounds
of the City and/or the School District of the City, or any of the facilities
thereof, other than upon official business,between the hours of 9:00 p.m. and
9:00 a.m. daily during the months of April, May, June, July, August and
September of each year, and between the hours of 6:00 p.m. and 9:00 a. m. daily
during the months of January, February, March, October, November and December
of each year.
(Ord. 6-93. Passed 7-22-93.)
1068.09  GROUP ACTIVITIES; ASSEMBLIES.
   (a)   No person in a park shall use any portion of the picnic areas or of
any of the buildings or structures therein for the purpose of holding picnics
to the exclusion of other persons, nor shall any person use such area and
facilities for an unreasonable time if the facilities are crowded.
   (b)   No person shall engage in, participate in, aid, form or organize any
assembly or group of people or make any speech or conduct any musical program
or festivities in a park unless a permit has been obtained from the Office of
Code Enforcement and unless such permit is carried by the person heading or
leading such activity, provided, however, that the provisions hereof shall not
apply to students' work when constituting a part of their educational
activities and under the immediate direction and supervision of the proper
school authorities, nor to any governmental agency within the scope of its
functions.
   (c)   Whenever any group, association or organization desires to use park
facilities for a particular purpose, such as picnics, parties, weddings or
theatrical or entertainment performances, a representative of such group,
association or organization shall first obtain a permit from the Office of Code
Enforcement for such purpose. Council may adopt an application form to be used
by the Office of Code Enforcement for such situations.
   The Chief Code Enforcement Officer shall grant the application if it appears
that the group, association or organization meets all other conditions
contained in the application. The application may contain a requirement for an
indemnity bond to protect the City from any liability of any kind and to
protect City property from damage.
(Ord. 14-78. Passed 5-10-78.)
1068.10  PERMIT APPLICATION AND ISSUANCE.
   (a)   Applications for a park permit shall be filed with the Chief Code
Enforcement Officer not less than twenty days nor more than 108 days before the
date on which it is proposed to conduct an activity such as is described in
Section
1068.09. Such application shall be sworn to and shall state:
      (1)   The name of the person or organization wishing to conduct such
activity;
      (2)   If the activity is proposed to be conducted for, on behalf of, or
by, any organization, then the name, address and telephone number of the
headquarters of the organization and of the authorized and responsible head of
such organization shall be given;
      (3)   The name, address and telephone number of the person or
organization to whom the permit is desired to be issued;
      (4)   The name, address and telephone number of the person who will be
the chairman of such activity and who will be responsible for its conduct;
      (5)   The date when such activity is to be conducted;
      (6)   The park or portion thereof for which such permit is desired;
      (7)   An estimate of the anticipated attendance; and
      (8)   The hour when such activity will start and terminate.
   (b)   The Chief Code Enforcement Officer shall grant and issue such park
permit if:
      (1)   The proposed activity or use of the park will not unreasonably
interfere with or detract from the general public enjoyment of the park.
      (2)   The proposed activity and use will not unreasonably interfere with
or detract from the promotion of public health, welfare, safety and recreation.
      (3)   The facilities desired have not been reserved for other use at the
day and hour required in the application.
      (4)   The conduct of such activity will not substantially interrupt the
safe and orderly movement of traffic.
      (5)   The conduct of such activity will not require the diversion of so
great a number of police officers of the City to properly police such activity
and the area contiguous thereto, as to prevent normal police protection to the
City.
      (6)   The conduct of such activity is not reasonably likely to cause
injury to persons or property or invite violence, crime or disorderly conduct.
      (7)   Such activity is not to be held for the sole purpose of advertising
any product, goods or event, and is not designated to be held purely for
private profit.
   (c)   Each park permit shall state the following:
      (1)   The date of the activity;
      (2)   The park or portion thereof to be used; and
      (3)   The hours when such activity shall start and terminate.
   (d)   The Chief Code Enforcement Officer shall act upon the application for
a park permit within ten days after filing of the same.
   (e)   The applicant shall post a bond with the City in the amount of fifteen
dollars ($15.00) to insure against damages or liability to the City.
(Ord. 14-78. Passed 5-10-78.)
1068.11  USE OF CITY BALLFIELDS.
   Permits for use of the City ballfields during the months of April, May,
June, July and August must be obtained from the Director of Recreation.
(Ord. 14-78. Passed 5-10-78.)
1068.12  RIVERVIEW PARK RENAMED GEORGE S. WARREN MEMORIAL PARK.
   The name of Riverview Park (formerly part of Parcel 9b, north of Connelly
Boulevard at the corner of South Water Avenue) is hereby changed to the George
S. Warren, Jr. Memorial Park.
(Res. 196-82. Passed 10-27-82.)
1068.99  PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
202.99 for general Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)
CHAPTER 1069
Public or Private Events on Public Property
1069.01   Defined terms.
1069.02   Prohibition.
1069.03   Application.
1069.04   Fee.
1069.05   Issuance; denial; appeal.
1069.06   Responsibility for costs.
1069.07   Violation.
1069.01  DEFINED TERMS.
   As used in this chapter:
   (a)   "Enclosed structure" is a building or similar edifice existing in such
form that it allows the occupants thereof to secure it from unwelcome intrusion
from the public or is constructed such that persons outside the structure are
unable to easily determine what activities are being undertaken within the
structure.
   (b)   “Event" is the planned gathering of 100 or more people outside the
confines of any building or enclosed structure.
   (c)   “Nonprofit applicant" is a person applying for a license pursuant to
Section
1069.03 of this chapter that has been in existence at least thirty-six months
prior to the date of the application with a verifiable history of community
service or eleemosynary activity.
   (d)   “Person" is any individual, trust, partnership, association, firm,
corporation, LLC, estate or other entity.
   (e)   "Public event" is an event that is organized such that it either
contemplates or necessarily extends into, uses, or occupies public property.
   (f)   “Public property" includes all roads, streets, alleys, walkways,
sidewalks, navigable waters of the Commonwealth, parking lots, parking garages,
and parks.
(Ord. 05-15.  Passed 7-16-15.)
1069.02  PROHIBITION.
   (a)   No person shall conduct or participate in any event or public event
not licensed by the City of Sharon pursuant to this chapter.
   (b)   No license shall be issued for any event or public event which:
      (1)   Will present a reasonable risk of affecting the free flow of
traffic on any State designated highway; or
      (2)   Has not received the appropriate license from the Pennsylvania
Liquor Control Board; or
      (3)   Does not identify available off street parking for vehicles
representing in number at least one third of the number of participants
expected to attend the event or public event.
(Ord. 05-15.  Passed 7-16-15.)
1069.03  APPLICATION.
   Any person wishing to obtain a license from the City of Sharon for
conducting an event shall make application to the City Manager on forms
prescribed by the City Manager but requiring as a minimum:
   (a)   The date of the proposed event or public event;
   (b)   The start and end time of the proposed event or public event;
   (c)   The location of the proposed event or public event;
   (d)   The anticipated number of participants in the proposed event or public
event;
   (e)   The purpose of the proposed event or public event;
   (f)   That the applicant has or will obtain general liability insurance of
not less than five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) covering the event or
public event naming the City of Sharon as an additional named insured if the
event or public event is reasonably anticipated to draw more than 1,000
persons;
   (g)   That if the event is to be a public event a description of the public
property to be directly impacted by the proposed public event;
   (h)   That if the applicant claims to be a nonprofit applicant that
sufficient information be submitted to verity its qualifications as such under
this chapter;
   (i)   That the applicant does or does not possess a valid license from the
Pennsylvania Liquor Control Board for serving alcoholic beverages at the site
of the proposed event or public event;
   (j)   Identification of the source and number of security proposed to be
provided by the licensee. 
(Ord. 05-15.  Passed 7-16-15.)
1069.04  FEE.
   No fee shall be charged for the issuance of a license under this chapter.
(Ord. 05-15.  Passed 7-16-15.)
1069.05  ISSUANCE; DENIAL; APPEAL.
   (a)   The City Manager shall, upon proper application, issue a license to
all applicants within thirty days of their filing of a completed application
unless the City Manager can articulate, in writing to the applicant, clear and
compelling evidence that the issuance of a license would be detrimental to the
health safety and welfare of any person.
   (b)   Any person denied a license by the City Manager may, within thirty
days of the denial, file a written appeal with the City Clerk therein
responding to the reasons advanced by the City Manager, and City Council will
then decide the matter after a public hearing on both the reasons advanced by
the City Manager and the applicant's response thereto.
   (c)   The hearing scheduled by City Council will be held within fifteen days
of the applicant's appeal and a decision shall be rendered at a public meeting
within three days of the conclusion of the public hearing.
(Ord. 05-15.  Passed 7-16-15.)
1069.06  RESPONSIBILITY FOR COSTS.
   All costs incurred by the City of Sharon as a direct result of the happening
of an event required to be licensed by this chapter, including public safety
overtime, cleanup costs, and damage repair shall be billed to a nonprofit
licensee to the extent that they exceed in total one thousand five hundred
dollars ($1,500.00). All other licensees shall be billed to the extent that
such costs exceed one thousand five hundred dollars ($1,500.00). All bills for
costs shall accrue interest at the rate of eighteen percent per annum. Failure
to pay costs shall be grounds for denial of any future license applications.
(Ord. 05-15.  Passed 7-16-15.)
1069.07  VIOLATION.
   Any person who shall violate any provisions of this chapter shall be fined
and required to pay not more than six hundred dollars ($600) for each violation
and/or serve a term of imprisonment not to exceed thirty days for each
violation. Each day, or portion thereof, that a violation exists or continues,
shall be deemed a separate offense, and punishable as such. In addition, the
City shall have the right to file a municipal lien against any property of any
applicant or licensee whose actions or inactions in violation of this chapter
requires the expenditure of any funds, or the incurring of any costs, by the
City of Sharon, said lien to be perfected in the manner as required by general
law.
(Ord. 05-15.  Passed 7-16-15.)
CHAPTER 1072
Sharon Free Public Library
1072.01   Authority to provide service.
1072.02   Financial support.
1072.03   Board of Directors.
1072.04   Treasurer’s bond.
1072.05   Receipts and disbursements.
1072.06   Reports.
1072.07   Grants.
1072.08   Contractors’ compliance with minimum wage and civil rights acts.
1072.09   Rules and regulations.
 
1072.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   The Library Code - see Act of June 14, 1961 (P.L. 324), as amended.
   Library Authority - see ADM. Ch.
276
   Smoking in public buildings - see GEN. OFF.
660.05
1072.01  AUTHORITY TO PROVIDE SERVICE.
   The Sharon Free Public Library is hereby authorized and designated to act
for and on behalf of Council to provide public library service to the residents
and taxpayers of the City and to fulfill the requirements of Section 13 of the
Regulations and Criteria for Grants under Title II of the Library Services and
Construction Act in Pennsylvania; the requirements of Section 214 of the
Appalachian Regional Development Act; and the requirements of the Library Code
of Pennsylvania, Act of June 14, 1961 (P.L. 324), 24 P.S. §§ 4101 et seq., all
as amended.
(Ord. 8-69.  Passed 2-26-69.)
1072.02  FINANCIAL SUPPORT.
   (a)   Council hereby agrees to maintain and/or assist in the maintenance of
the Sharon Free Public library in accordance with the provisions of Section 401
of the Library Code, the act of June 14, 1961 (P.L. 324), as amended, at a
level of financial support that will insure that the Library will have an
annual income from local sources of not less than two dollars and twenty-five
cents ($2.25) per capita for the population of the City so as to be able to
qualify annually for State financial aid in accordance with Section 303(1) of
the Library Code, as amended.
(Ord. 8-69.  Passed 2-26-69.)
   (b)   Council reserves the right to impose a line item budget relative to
the funds allocated to the Library by Council for its operation.
(Ord. 7-78.  Passed 2-22-78.)
1072.03  BOARD OF DIRECTORS.
   In accordance with Section 411 of the Library Code, Council shall appoint
seven people to serve as the City's representatives on the Board of Directors
of the Sharon Free Public Library, each representative to serve three years,
the terms to expire in different years.  The first appointees shall be
appointed for terms as follows: Two members for one year; two members for two
years; and three members for three years. Subsequent vacancies are to be filled
by Council. All members shall serve until their successors have been appointed.
No member of the Board shall receive any salary for his or her service as such.
The Board shall elect its own officers.  No less than two members of the Board
of Directors shall be members of Council.
(Ord. 6-00.  Passed 4-27-00.)
 1072.04   TREASURER'S BOND.
   In accordance with Section 412 of the Library Code, the Treasurer of the
Board of Directors of the Library shall give bond to the City with a
satisfactory surety, in such amount as the Board may determine.
(Ord. 38-82. Passed 12-21-82.)
 1072.05   RECEIPTS AND DISBURSEMENTS.
   In accordance with Section 413 of the Library Code, all moneys appropriated
for the maintenance of the Library and all moneys, if any, received from other
sources for its use, shall be under the control of Council, to the extent
permitted by law, and may be disbursed under the direction of the Board of
Directors of the Library with the approval of Council, to the extent that such
approval is permitted or required by law. The Board shall have all of the
rights and duties delegated to such Board by the Library Code and shall present
a financial report to the City annually. The City shall arrange to have the
accounts of the Treasurer of the Board of Directors audited annually as in the
case of other Municipal expenditures.
(Ord. 39-82. Passed 12-21-82.)
1072.06  REPORTS.
   The Board of Directors shall prepare and present to the City such reports as
are required by Section 414 of the Library Code and shall give free library
service to the residents and taxpayers of the City as provided in Section 415
of the Library Code.
(Ord. 8-69.  Passed 2-26-69.)
 1072.07   GRANTS.
   All buildings constructed and/or property purchased with the aid of Library
Services and Construction Act Grants or other Grants must be titled in the name
of the City and all expenditures and contracts pertaining to the same must be
approved by Council.
(Ord. 8-69. Passed 2-26-69.)
1072.08  CONTRACTORS' COMPLIANCE WITH MINIMUM WAGE AND CIVIL RIGHTS ACTS.
   All contractors, subcontractors and materialmen employed to do construction
work must comply with the provisions of the Davis-Bacon Act, a minimum wage
law, and the requirements of the Contract Work Hours Standard Act, the Copeland
Act and the Civil Rights Act of 1964, all as amended.
(Ord. 8-69. Passed 2-26-69.)
1072.09  RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   The Board of Directors shall have the power to promulgate its own rules and
regulations for the purpose of carrying out the powers and duties relating to
libraries in conformity with the Library Code of Pennsylvania and its Advisory
Council on Library Development.
(Ord. 8-69. Passed 2-26-69.)
1072.99  PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
202.99 for general Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)

TITLE TWO - Planning
         Chap.
1220.   City Planning Commission.
         Chap.
1222.   Mercer County Subdivision Regulations.
         Chap.

CHAPTER 1220
City Planning Commission
1220.01   Purpose; recommendations of Commission.
1220.02   Appropriations, grants and gifts.
1220.03   Creation.
1220.04   Membership; compensation.
1220.05   Appointments, terms and vacancies.
1220.06   Members of existing commissions.
1220.07   Residency required.
1220.08   Removal of members.
1220.09   Conduct of business.
1220.10   Powers and duties.
1220.11   Checking account; annual report.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Planning agencies - see Penna. Mun. Plan. Code, Art. II
   Joint Planning Commissions - see Penna. Mun. Plan. Code, Art. XI
1220.01  PURPOSE; RECOMMENDATIONS OF COMMISSION.
   In conformity with the provisions of the Act of July 21, 1968, No. 247, it
is the intent, purpose and scope of this chapter to protect and promote safety,
health and morals; to accomplish a coordinated development of the City; to
provide for the general welfare by guiding and protecting amenity, convenience,
future governmental, economic, practical and social and cultural facilities,
development and growth, as well as the improvement of governmental processes
and functions; to guide uses of land and structures, type and location of
streets, public grounds and other facilities; and to permit the City to
minimize such problems as may presently exist or which may be foreseen. It is
the further intent of this chapter that any recommendations made by the
Planning Commission to Council shall be advisory only.
(Ord. 9-70. Passed 3-25-70.)
1220.02  APPROPRIATIONS, GRANTS AND GIFTS.
   Appropriations may be made as Council sees fit and Council may accept gifts,
grants or bequests from public and private sources for the purpose of carrying
out the powers and duties conferred by this chapter. In addition, Council may
enter into agreements regarding the acceptance or utilization of such grants,
gifts or bequests.
(Ord. 9-70. Passed 3-25-70.)
1220.03  CREATION.
   There is hereby created in and for the City a planning commission to be
known as the City of Sharon Planning Commission, or just the City Planning
Commission, or just the Planning Commission.
(Ord. 9-70. Passed 3-25-70.)
1220.04  MEMBERSHIP; COMPENSATION.
   The Planning Commission shall be comprised of seven members. All members of
the Commission shall serve without compensation, but may be reimbursed for
necessary and reasonable expenses. However, elected or appointed officers or
employees of the City shall not, by reason of membership thereon, forfeit the
right to exercise the powers, perform the duties or receive the compensation of
the City offices held by them during such membership.
(Ord. 9-70. Passed 3-25-70; Ord. 8-75. Passed 3-12-75; Ord. 23-92. Passed 10-
21-92.)
1220.05  APPOINTMENTS, TERMS AND VACANCIES.
   All members of the Planning Commission shall be appointed and approved by
Council. The term of each of the members shall be for four years, or until his
successor is appointed and qualified, except that the terms of the members
first appointed pursuant to this chapter shall be so fixed so that on
Commissions of nine members or less, not more than three shall be reappointed
or replaced during any future calendar year. The Chairman of the Commission
shall promptly notify Council concerning vacancies on the Commission, and such
vacancies shall be filled by Council for the unexpired term.
1220.06  MEMBERS OF EXISTING COMMISSIONS.
   The members of any existing Planning Commission established under former
ordinances shall continue in office until the end of the term for which they
were appointed. However, their successors shall be appointed as provided in
this chapter. If a vacancy occurs otherwise than by expiration of term, it
shall be filled by appointment for the unexpired term according to Section
1220.05. Should Council desire to increase the number of members of an already
existing Planning Commission, the additional members shall be appointed as
provided in this chapter. If Council determines to reduce the number of members
on any existing Planning Commission in the future, such reduction shall be
effected by allowing the terms of the existing members to expire and by making
no new appointments to fill their vacancy. Any reduction or increase in
membership shall be by ordinance.
(Ord. 9-70. Passed 3-25-70.)
1220.07  RESIDENCY REQUIRED.
   All members of the Planning Commission shall be residents of the City.
(Ord. 9-70. Passed 3-25-70.)
1220.08  REMOVAL OF MEMBERS.
   Any member of a Planning Commission once qualified and appointed may be
removed from office because of malfeasance, misfeasance or nonfeasance in
office or for other just cause by a majority vote of Council, taken after the
member has received fifteen days advance notice of the intent to take such a
vote. A hearing shall be held before Council in connection with the vote if the
member requests it in writing. Any appointment to fill a vacancy created by
removal shall be only for the unexpired term. All decisions of Council shall be
deemed final.
(Ord. 9-70. Passed 3-25-70.)
1220.09  CONDUCT OF BUSINESS.
   The Planning Commission shall elect its own Chairman and Vice-Chairman and
create and fill such other offices as it may determine. Officers shall serve
annual terms and may succeed themselves. The Commission may make and alter
bylaws and rules and regulations to govern its procedures consistent with the
ordinances of the City and the laws of the Commonwealth. The Commission shall
keep a full record of its business and shall annually make a written report to
Council by December 1 of each year of its activities. Interim reports may be
made as often as may be necessary, or as requested by Council.
(Ord. 9-70. Passed 3-25-70.)
1220.10  POWERS AND DUTIES.
   (a)   The Planning Commission shall have the power and shall be required to:
      (1)   Prepare the comprehensive plan for the development of the City as
set forth in the Act of July 21, 1968, No. 247, and present it for the
consideration of Council;
      (2)   Maintain and keep on file records of its action. All records and
files of the Commission shall be in the possession of Council.
   (b)   The Planning Commission shall, upon request of Council:
      (1)   Prepare and present for consideration to Council, and, after
adoption, maintain for Council, an official map, and make recommendations to
Council on proposed changes on such map as set forth;
      (2)   Prepare and present to Council a zoning ordinance and make
recommendations to Council on proposed amendments to it;
      (3)   Prepare and administer subdivision and land development
regulations; (4) Prepare and administer planned residential development
regulations;
      (5)   Prepare and present to Council a building code and make
recommendations to Council on proposed amendments thereto;
      (6)   Prepare and present to Council a housing code and make
recommendations to Council on proposed amendments thereto;
      (7)   Hold public hearings and meetings;
      (8)   Require from other departments and agencies of the City such
available information as relates to the work of the Planning Commission;
      (9)   In the performance of its functions, enter upon any land to make
examinations and surveys either after permission has been obtained from the
owner or after public notices; and
      (10)   Do such other act or make such studies as may be necessary to
fulfill the duties and obligations imposed by this chapter.
   (c)   In the performance of its powers and duties, any act or recommendation
of the Planning Commission which involves engineering consideration shall be
subject to approval of the City Engineer or the Director of Public Works.
(Ord. 9-70. Passed 3-25-70.)
1220.11  CHECKING ACCOUNT; ANNUAL REPORT.
   (a)   The City Planning Commission is hereby authorized to establish its own
checking account with funds budgeted for the year.
   (b)   The City Planning Commission shall present a financial report to
Council in December of each year and shall return all unexpended funds to the
City at the end of each calendar year.
   (c)   The Chairman and Secretary-Treasurer shall be the authorized officers
to sign all checks drawn on this account.
(Res. 17-76. Passed 2-11-76. )

shall be substituted the term "Sharon City Council. "
(Ord. 10-79. Passed 5-2-79.)

   EDITOR'S NOTE: Resolution 2-72, passed February 9, 1972, authorized the City
to join and associate itself with the City of Farrell, the Boroughs of
Sharpsville, Wheatland, West Middlesex and Clark, the Townships of Hickory,
Jefferson and South Pymatuning, and the County of Mercer, in the creation of a
regional planning commission to be known as the Mercer County Regional Planning
Commission, a successor to the Shenango Valley Regional Planning Commission,
pursuant to the Pennsylvania Municipalities Planning Code. Resolution 162-80,
passed September 10, 1980, consented to the admission of Wilmington Township to
the Commission. Resolution 230-88, passed November 22, 1988, consented to the
admission of Perry Township to the Commission. Resolution 164-92, passed July
22, 1992, consented to the admission of Jackson Township to the Commission.
Resolution 195-95, passed September 28, 1995, consented to the admission of
Liberty Township to the Commission. Ordinance 2393, passed January 27, 1994,
adopted the Amended Articles of Agreement of the Commission. Resolution 216-95,
passed October 25, 1995, endorsed the Commission's Comprehensive Plan.
   Copies of the foregoing may be obtained, at cost, from the City Clerk.
   There are no sections in
Chapter 1224. This chapter has been established to provide a place for cross
